One thing I love about the brand is the range of sample and travel size products they offer. I'm big on testing smaller sizes of products instead of going whole hog right away and buying the full size bottles. I feel like I don't waste as much, because who really knows what happens to the products you return? (but really, if you do know, please share!) 

Anywho, there were some winners and some runner ups; here's the list!

Skin Rescue Deep Cleanser with Red Clay- Love this! it's very simple and the scent is minimal, but it really does give a deep clean! I love this for using in the evening as my second cleanse to really get the gunk of the day off my face. Will be purchasing the full size! 

Face Cleanser- this is okay as your basic cleanser. It didn't break me out, so that's a plus, but I didn't really love it for removing makeup and while it's not fragranced, the scent kind of put me off. However, if you're looking for a simple cleanser to do the job, I think this would work well! 

Facial Radiance Pads- These are amazing! I've been experiencing a lot of texture in certain areas of my face lately and kind of stumped as to what to do about it. I'd never really gotten into chemical exfoliants before, but I'm really enjoying these! I've been using them 2-3 times weekly as my first step in the mornings, in place of my normal toner. I'm definitely noticing smoother, brighter skin! Purchasing the full size of these as soon as I run out. Another note about this product—the sample size packaging is amazing. It's perfect for travel! I love that they went with a resealable packet as opposed to the foil packets you open once then have to root around for a ziploc baggy to put the remaining ones in so they don't dry out. 

Skin Rescue Daily Face Cream- This is my new night cream (rebel I know). I've been struggling for a simple cream to use at night that isn't aimed at intense moisturizing or intense anything. My skin is very sensitive, and does produce a decent amount of oil overnight, so a lighter night cream works better for me. This fits the bill! It's lightweight, has no scent, and does the job! I got ballsy and ordered the full size straight away with this, so i'm set! I may start using this in the mornings as well, if I ever fall out of love with the Fresh Rose Hydrating Gel Cream.

Do you have any favorites from First Aid Beauty?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: BEST BRONZERS FOR FAIR SKIN
item.content:encoded:
If you’re fair skinned like me, finding the right bronzing products to help you not blind people with the light reflecting from your body can be quite the experience. Bronzers can show up orange-y on me when they don’t seem to have an orange tone in sight in the pan. I’ve tried many, many products to achieve that healthy glow and found two bronzers I recommend to anyone with skin tones close to mine:

The Body Shop Honey Bronzer in Light Matte- This is it, you guys. It’s the #1 perfect-for-pale-skin bronzer for all seasons, but specifically Winter and Spring. I’ve been using it for a few years and nothing has topped it. It’s really light—so us pale girls are probably the only who can make use of it, but it’s perfect. It’s right in the middle in the pigment department, enough that it makes an instant difference, but not so much that you’ll have trouble blending it out. I like that I can build it up when necessary. This is the bronzer that makes people tell me I look tan. Me? Tan? THANKS! 

Tarte Amazonian Clay Waterproof Bronzer in Park Ave Princess—This is my all-time favorite one for summer. It’s definitely something I can only use in the summer when I have some color. I do go light handed with this, but it gives a gorgeous warm glow. There’s definitely some shimmer in this one, but it doesn’t look crazy on the skin. I can't say I've ever tested that waterproof claim, but the Tarte Amazonian Clay products are known for their lasting power. Given the darker color and shimmer, I tend to grab a duo-fiber brush to apply, and while concentrating on the normal bronzing areas, I end up dusting it pretty much all over my face. Topped with a gorgeous pale gold highlight like Becca’s Moonstone, you’ll look like a sun goddess. I currently have a "deluxe" sample size of this bad boy and it's lasted me quite a while. 

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="4608.0"] L to R; Tarte, The Body Shop [/caption]

What are your favorite bronzing products?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: MAC STAPLES: A HAUL
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="4608.0"] Top to bottom: Teddy, Soar, Patisserie, Velvet Teddy [/caption]

I had a bit of a stroll through the mac counter last week and while I told myself to stay strong, I caved a bit. Who’s surprised? Not me. To justify the spend a bit, I will say, I stuck to picking up some staples. I have tried mac products many times in the past, and always been pretty loyal to their brushes when I want to go high end. Who doesn’t own multiple 217’s?. Luckily, my local mac counter was only out of one of the items I had my eyes on, which is a rare occasion when you’re looking for their cult products! 

I ended up picking up two lipsticks in the shades Patisserie and Velvet Teddy, one lip pencil in Soar, and one eye kohl in Teddy. 

I’m not sure how much explanation any of these beauties require; but i’ll give it a quick stab anyhow. 

Patisserie (Lustre): This is a great everyday shade to have on hand for any makeup look. It’s a light peachy-pink with a bit of gold shimmer running through it. Since it’s a lustre finish it’s a bit more sheer and light. If you’re someone who likes to have a simple lip on rather than going bare—you’ll get a ton of use out of this one. 

Velvet Teddy (Matte): Swoon. On the matte side of the spectrum, this little number is my new obsession. It’s such a subtle muted beige color but it doesn’t wash me out like I was suspecting it might. The original matte formula from Mac is comfortable and long wearing. 5 stars from me!  

Soar: As everyone else has this guy, I figured there was something to it. While it is a beautiful formula and great color, I feel like I have some way cheaper dupes in my collection. You might see a post about this soon. It’s pretty much the same color as my lips, so it goes well under most nude or pink shades for me. Definitely one I will get use out of, but might not spend the cash on it a second time. 

Teddy: Swoon again. Another one I’ve been wearing since I brought this little loot home. If you have blue eyes—you need this eyeliner. A warm, dark, chocolatey brown with a bronze shimmer in it, it’s a dream for making lighter peepers really stand out. I like that it’s definitely a brown, but it’s still dark enough to create those classic smokey eye looks with. I’ve been lining my top eyelid with this and using a pencil brush to really blend it out. Then I either leave it at that or I’ll pop a champagne shade in the center of the eyelid to add to the dimension of the look. The wear time is wonderful and all around I’m very happy with this one.  

What are your favorites from Mac? Are there any other cult products of theirs I need in my life? (hint: I'm sure there are)
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: TRIED AND TESTED: MILANI + OLE HENRICKSEN
item.content:encoded:
Ole Henricksen Ultimate Lift Eye Gel Roll On—This was a great find at my local TJ Maxx! Whenever i’m there I scour the cosmetics and skincare aisles for gems like this. (don’t worry, this doesn’t mean it’s hard to get—you can find it on amazon!) I scored this for around $10, and I really like it! The roller ball is soon nice and cooling. I’d be lying if I said I’d love just the metal roller ball even if there wasn’t a nice eye gel in there as well! The gel itself is so light and refreshing. I only use this in the mornings, and I find it really helps my eye bags, helping me to look less like I haven’t slept in 5 years. If you can get ahold of this one—I highly recommend it! 

Milani Prime Shield (mattifying and pore-minimizing)—I picked up this primer thinking it could be similar to something like the Smashbox photo finish primer, which I’ve always enjoyed. I know some people really aren’t into the silicone-feel primers, but personally I love them! These formulas do a great job of filling in my larger pores and smoothing out my skin. I had high hopes for this Milani offering, as most of their products which I’ve tried have pleasantly surprised me. 
I’ve been trying this one out for a few weeks and I’m still kind of “meh” about it, really. I’ll likely use it up, as I find my foundation applies nicely overtop, and it does smooth out some of the texture in my skin. However, in comparison to similar formulas, I find it a bit oily in texture. Also, it’s meant to mattify oily skin and while it helped a bit around my nose, my forehead ended up much more oily by the end of the day than normal. 
I also can’t say that it helped my makeup last any longer, but I wasn’t necessarily expecting that, that’s what setting sprays are for!
All in all, I think it’s a good option for smoothing the skin, but not for oil control. As I said, i’ll probably use this up, or pass it on to a friend with slightly drier skin than mine.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: NUDE LIP LOVES
item.content:encoded:
Nude lips are quite in at the moment, with the 90's trend of brown shades popping up on makeup counters. While I love a good browny nude, I tend to lean more on the pink side of nudes for my perfect shade. We've all been there where we thought a color was going to give us an amazing nude lip and it ends up looking like concealer. (yikes) On my pale skin, i’m all about that hint of dusty pink in a nude. I also tend to lean towards glossy or satin finish when choosing lighter lip colors. Here are some of my favorites:

Milani Color Statement Lip Liner in Nude
A pink-brown liner that I tend to just spread all over my lips and either leave it at that or put another color on top of it. This baby lasts, I’ll put it on in the morning and don’t reapply until after lunch. If you’re putting another lipstick on top of it—it will truly extend it’s wear. I love the formula of these Milani liners, and they're under $4. Win. 

Revlon Lip Butter in Berry Smoothie
I think I can speak for most lip product addicts when I say that the Revlon Lip Butters are a no brainer. I started with just one shade, and started picking up a few more each time they were in range until I had to stop myself. While I love many, many of the shades, Berry Smoothie fits my dusty pink nude for everyday category perfectly. The color is similar to my lip’s natural shade but a touch darker, and there’s some beautiful shimmer running through it. Very easy to top up throughout the day as I find you don't really even need a mirror! 

NARS Satin Lip Pencil in Rikugien
I have a few of the NARS pencils floating around in my stash, but this one is my favorite of the bunch. This shade might be the exact color of my lips naturally, with some shimmer in it, and the formula feels great on the lips. Mine’s getting small; so seeing as we’re getting into my favorite seasons to wear this, a new tube will likely find it’s way into my Sephora cart soon!

Urban Decay lipstick in Liar
This shade seams to be discontinued(sad face), but this shade is quite similar. Probably the most pink of the options, I love this to pair with darker, more dramatic eye looks. I’ve worn it to loads of weddings and events, it’s really comfortable and lasts decently long. A staple in my collection!

NYx Butter Gloss in Tiramisu
I’ve recently fallen for the NYX butter glosses. I already have 5 more colors loaded up in my basket on ulta.com. Pretty soon I’ll be doing a post on my top drugstore beauty picks, an these are set to make the cut so I won’t go on too much about them here. Just this—you must try them!

Bite Beauty Lush Fruit Lipgloss in Cocoa
This is a thick, very opaque, shiny gloss. I’m in love with the color and the smell. I’m usually not going gaga over lip products that smell like cake or candy, but these smell like fresh fruit! It’s so nice. This gloss is a bit sticky, however, so avoid it if you’re going outside on a windy day. The color is a really neutral, cool-toned dusty pink nude. (could I have used any more adjectives?) But it’s great no matter the look you’re going for, and that bit of stick does mean that it lasts well; which is why it’s high up on the list for me!

H&M Lipstick in Cream Chestnut
I’ve raved about this previously on my blog, and for good reason. While the formula isn’t the most luxurious I’ve ever used, they’re still comfortable and look great on the lips. This color is more of a browny nude compared to the rest, and as you can see from the photos it’s well loved. I keep this in my purse at all times! Plus, the price tag is so nice! H&M did really well with this one.

What are your go-to nude shades?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: CURRENTLY LOVING VOL. 2
item.content:encoded:
NYX Sculpt + Highlight duo in Ivory/Taupe—I’ve been getting a bit adventurous with the contouring, and seeing how the warmer months are on their way, I decided to experiment with a cream/liquid contour. I picked up this NYX offering when it launched thinking I usually like their products and they often have great dupes for some rather pricy options. I was pleasantly surprised here! While I don’t enjoy the highlight end of it, the contour is quite nice! The highlight just didn’t sit on my skin well. But the contour—it’s lovely. The color is really great for us pale gals, and it blends out quite nicely. It’s a doe-foot applicator that you use to swipe on the product where you want it. It’s pretty pigmented so it’s really nice to be able to be pretty precise. My current favorite way to wear this is to paint my face up with this before applying a light to medium coverage base. I find it looks really natural that way.  

Create Cosmetics Moisturizer- I got this after hearing many gals on youtube mention this brand. I was looking for a different night cream, and I am loving this! It’s really hydrating and doesn’t sink into the skin as well as others i’ve tried, which is why I strictly use it at night. But the lactic acid and tea tree oil combo have my skin soft as a baby’s bottom when I wake up! 

NARS Eyeshadow Duo in Isolde- again with the warm tones! I’ve had this for a while now (see a haul post where I got it here) and loved pulling it out on occasion, but lately it’s been a staple on the days I actually wear eyeshadow. I blend the darker shade all over the lid and through the crease, then bring the lovely golden number into the center of my lids. 

There’s a new book subscription service in my life and it goes by the name of Scribd. It’s $8.99 for 3 e-books and 1 audio book a month! Hallelujah! There’s also a list of “selects” every month which are free for you to consume. If you’re a big reader, you must check out Scribd! I’ve learned the power of audiobooks and how I read so many more books because I can listen to them when i’m cooking or cleaning. It’s been amazing! 

Voluspa Santiago Huckleberry candle- yum, yum, yum. A friend of mine gifted this candle to me, and it’s been a big time love of mine lately. It’s sweet and lovely and I’ve been burning it nonstop! 

Meal prepping- here’s something I never thought i’d be into. I’ve never been good at eating the same meal for multiple days. I love my tastebuds and they deserve variety! But, in effort to save some cash by avoiding Panera, Piada, the local burger joint, etc… I’ve been trying to pack my lunch to work. This has gotten me into the habit of picking one recipe and making it close to the beginning of the week then splitting it up for lunches. I usually do this on Tuesdays, as I work from my home and can use my lunch hour to slave away! I like to pick one protein that’s packed with flavor and get that all ready. I’ll get some cauliflower rice or spaghetti squash going as well. Then, each day i’ll mix up what sides I put in with that protein; sometimes spinach & salad fixings, sometimes veg. It’s really been working out well for me, and i’m only getting more adventurous with the recipes!  

What are you currently loving?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: NEW SILKY HAIR GO-TO'S
item.content:encoded:
As I’ve talked about before, not too long ago I put my hair through some things. Lots of processing which completely dried it out worse than I’ve experienced before. I even had about four inches lopped off to take care of some of the damage. Now, this was entirely my own fault because I wanted that sleek grey hair! And I got it. And I loved it. For a short time :)

Since then, i’ve been on the hunt for the right products to repair my hair without overloading it. Before I went grey, my hair was actually quite limp, lifeless, and got greasy quite quickly. Post-grey, it's completely different. I'd still call it lifeless, but also dry as can be. 

So, the new (ish) L’Oreal Extraordinary Oil range is a great option for me! I’ve been testing out the shampoo, conditioner, and serum for about a week, and I am overall pretty pleased with these products! 

First off, they smell so good. Secondly, they really hydrate and replenish my hair without causing any buildup or greasiness. 

The Lustrous Oil Serum is by far my favorite item from the range, as hair serums/oils are a staple product for me. If you do a lot of heat styling with your hair—you’ve got to start using oils, they’ll change your hair! 

This oil has helped a ton with the ends of my hair, I apply a hefty amount to the ends before blow-drying, and any excess left on my hands i’ll run lightly through the roots. My hair would be in complete shambles without a product like this. 

The conditioner comes in second for me; as I see it as a great conditioner but it didn’t really wow me. I am really finicky with conditioners, and honestly tend to use masks a lot instead. But I will definitely be using this up as my regular conditioner option! 

And in third place from what i’ve tried, the shampoo. This really isn’t to do with the product, I think it leaves my hair feeling clean and soft. However, I do have very cool-toned, ashy blonde hair, so I prefer to use a deep violet toning shampoo to keep any and all warmth from creeping into my locks. 

Overall, if you’re struggling with dry, hard to manage hair—I think this range will be great for you! The smell is great, and you’ll have silky hair in no time!

Have you tried these yet?

 

 

 

These product samples were kindly sent to me for review by L'Oreal Paris via Influenster.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: ROSY OUTLOOK
item.content:encoded:
Lately I've been very drawn to products with rose involved somehow. I've always loved rose scented things, but with my such oily skin in the past, the hydrating properties of rose products always scared me away. Now that my skin is a messy combination that i'm never quite sure what to do with, i've been really drawn to rose products to sooth the more dry and flaky parts of my skin. 

I've been using the Thayer's Witch Hazel with Aloe Vera in the Rose Petal scent for a few years now, as I just find it to be my perfect toner. If you've not tried Thayer's Witch Hazel and you have any issues with oiliness in the t-zone or large pore, you've got to try it! They have tons of different scents, and the aloe vera really helps soothe the skin. So, i'll use this morning + night as my toner step on a cotton pad, adding a few drops of tea tree oil when I'm having a breakout. I don't see myself trying a new toner for a long time, we've had a good two year relationship and still going strong! (P.S.— my boyfriend also uses this stuff and loves it!) 

The next rose product i've used, loved, and recently repurchased as the warmer months are creeping up is the Fresh Rose Hydrating Gel Cream. This stuff, guys, it's amazing. I originally had a sample of it in the fall, and when it got super cold I was looking for something a bit heavier, but it's so perfect for spring-summer-fall temps! If you're like me and can have an oil slick for a t-zone, but flaky, dry cheeks that makeup won't even adhere to (le sigh) this formula is perfect! Since it's more of a gel, you're getting the hydration needed but not slathering on a thick cream that can cause oil. The smell is divine and I find it provides an excellent base for makeup. I've got my eyes on the rose face mask from the line next! 

The last rosy addition to my collection is a bit of a pricey buy that you may consider a princess product, but I've been eyeing it up for the longest time. Oh, my, the Dior Creme de Rose Smoothing Plumping Lip Balm. Swoon. It's every bit of the fabulousness that you'd expect. I apply a hefty amount of this morning and night (and sometimes in between.. :) ) and it leaves my lips so hydrated without being thick and sticky. Perfection. 

What rose products should I try next?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: CURRENTLY LOVING
item.content:encoded:
L'Oreal True Match Lumi—This has quickly become my go-to drugstore foundation. I haven't purchased another since I discovered it! It's a medium coverage foundation that builds up quite nicely when needed, but always looks fresh and natural. It's not overly dewy, but just looks like skin. They've recently come out with this formula in cushion form, and i'm interested to try it out! 

Loreal Infallible Pro Contour in Light— Loving this! Plain and simple. Contour is a great shade and the highlight is beautiful. See a more in depth review here. 

Ren Clear Calm 3 Replenishing Gel Cream— This. Wowza. Its been working wonders on my weird winter skin. My skin is usually combo-oily but really goes wacky in the winter and is basically dry + oily at the same time. I like to step up the moisturizer game during the colder months to combat this and this Ren offering has been perfect. It’s meant to be used to replenish skin that’s also being treated with anti-acne products, so that’s a huge bonus for me, as my normal breakout-banishing products can leave my poor face pretty parched.

 

 

 

Tarte Amazonian Clay Blush in Peaceful- This is a deluxe size sample I’ve had for a long time. It’s a bit warmer than I’d usually go for in the winter, but I think the warmth is exactly what my complexion needs right now! It's a pinky apricot shade with some gold shimmer running through which I think would suit many skin tones, but it doesn't overpower me and my paleness. 

Lush Rosy Cheeks Fresh Face mask— If you haven't tried a fresh face mask from lush, go! buy! try! They're masks you keep in the fridge to keep cool which lets them give an amazing sensation when applied to your skin. This mask smells like a divine bunch of roses (due to the rose clay present) and also has calamine in it to really soothe an aggravated complexion. I find it's perfect for a small pamper session and leaves my skin feeling refreshed. I slap a thick layer on, let it dry, then gently remove with a damp cloth.

Daniel Wellington Classic Sheffield in Silver—This was a Christmas gift from my lovely boyfriend. (although he'd tell you Santa got it for me) I was really amazed when I unwrapped this beauty. I've been eyeing it up for a long time, but never really said much about it. That's good researching, Nick! I love how classy it is. Simple, no fuss, and looks stunning with any outfit. I wear it when i'm getting all dolled up or with jeans + trainers. It's a staple for those who need a watch that looks great and can be worn everyday without fail.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WINTER LIP LOVES + AND A BLAST OF NOSTALGIA
item.content:encoded:
Oh, Pride & Prejudice. Some may know this, but it's my all-time favorite novel. I first read it in high school (and yes, I still have that first copy of it), and have loved it ever since. I've read it easily 20 times, and every time I am captivated by the characters and their story. It takes me back to the first time I read it, when I was nothing more than annoyed I had summer reading assignments. It's funny how you don't realize how much something will stick with you. I find myself picking it up every now and again when I'm not sure what to read next and want something I know I will enjoy. I've collected different editions of the book over the years, and this is my favorite one of my collection. 

Normally, in the colder months I fall into the world of deep, bold, berry lip colors. I love a good deep plum or burgundy. But this year I've taken more to the neutral side of life and become obsessed with two colors that will be lifetime loves. 

The first being the Kat Von D Everlasting Liquid Lipstick in the shade Lolita II. This baby is gorgeous. It's described as a 'terra cotta nude' which is spot on. Slightly orangey, slightly brown, all amazing. This is also one of my favorite liquid lipstick formulas-super long lasting and easy to apply. It's got a much thinner consistency than some others out there which I find really helps to not go overboard and keep your lips feeling comfortable. 

The second is the Revlon Colorburst Matte Balm in Sultry. This is a plumy brown shade that’s pretty subtle but still fabulous. The real attraction here comes with the formula. These are the most comfortable matte lip colors on the market, hands down. Since they’re like a balm, they feel very hydrating. They’ve also got this minty smell which is a huge plus for me since I love all things mint! This color is bold enough to be seen buts subtle and neutral enough that it works with so many different looks.  

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="4608.0"] Left: Sultry Right: Lolita II [/caption]
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: HOW TO CARE FOR HIGHLY PROCESSED HAIR
item.content:encoded:
Say hello to granny hair! Recently, I decided to take the plunge and go gray. I’d had light to platinum blonde for some time now, and I wanted to go for something different. It all started when I got the L'Oreal silver shampoo. I got this to keep the platinum color cool and ashy. But, it resulted in a happy accident: it turned my hair a silvery-lavender color. The product itself is a very deep, rich shade of violet. I was really enjoying the color I was getting from the shampoo, but it wasn’t very even across my locks and it didn’t last very long. (I try not to use the shampoo for each wash because I found it a bit too drying)
So, I hit up my salon and made the appointment to let the professionals take me to full-on granny. And I loved it!

Only problem is, my hair is now as dry as a desert. It was dry before, but man, this is crazy. With the bleaching to take care of my roots & then the toning to bring it to the icy silver color I wanted, we put my strands through the ringer. So, i’ve been using some products for extra moisture and strength. Some are old friends of mine, and others are new discoveries. Here’s the lineup:

L’Oreal Professionale Silver Shampoo:
As I described, it’s a deep violet colored shampoo that keeps all the brassiness at bay.

Davines Nou Nou hair mask:
This is a new purchase recommended by my hair stylist. It’s a thick, creamy mask created from all natural ingredients and smells like black tea! It makes my hair so silky smooth & was one of the only things to soothe my locks right after having the processes done. I use this in place of conditioner every other wash, concentrating it on the ends of my hair. I love this so much that it's hitting must-have status for me! 

Redken All-Soft Conditioner:
This conditioner has been a favorite of mine for a long time. The entire All-Soft range is fabulous. Not to mention it smells amazing. It’s a great everyday conditioner for the days you’re not using a mask.

Treseme Keratin Smooth Heat Protectant:
I’m not sure if this product has been reformulated as the packaging is different, but I’ve always been into the Treseme heat protectant sprays—they do the job! (and the price point is fabulous)

Healing Time!:
After doing a multiple process color session on your hair, it really does need time to recover. It’s taken a few weeks for my hair to feel somewhat normal again. Especially when you’re using bleach, you’re really drying out your strands so they need some time to bounce back! I try to skip the heat tools as much as possible as well to reduce the damage going on.

Tips for grey/pastel colors:

These shades tend to fade pretty quickly, since they’re so light already and sitting on top of bleach. Because of this, I wouldn’t use any shampoo that isn’t intended for color treated hair. If you’ve got platinum/grey/lavender going on, a purple shampoo is a must if you want to extend the life of your color. I’ve also stocked up on my favorite dry shampoo to help reduce the amount of washing so they color will last a bit longer.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: NEW PRODUCT REVIEW: L'OREAL INFALLIBLE PRO CONTOUR
item.content:encoded:
It seems like most drugstore beauty brands are beginning to bring out contour palettes, which is long awaited by those of us who don't want to commit to those expensive palettes that have 3 colors you'll never touch... 

The first one I could get my hands on was the L'Oreal Infallible Pro-Contour.  It's an addition to their Infallible line which is home to many of my most loved products from the brand. I was also most excited about this one in particular because the contour shade is actually a cool-toned, ashy brown (as a contour should be), and the Light shade is actually light enough for fair skinned peeps like myself. 

Now, ignoring that weird looking brush that comes with it, I pretty much love this little duo. The contour shade, apart from being a great color, isn't super pigmented. This might frustrate those who like a sharp, very defined cheek, but I think it's great. It's definitely buildable, so you can work it up to be quite dramatic. But, since it starts out on the subtle side, it's pretty hard to go overboard and makes it perfect for those just starting out in the sculpting game. 

The highlight shade is a very pretty pale gold shimmer color that's also pretty subtle, which I think is perfect for the colder months where you're not too keen on being a disco ball. That being said, when going out a few nights ago I layered this on top of my Becca Shimmering Skin Perfecter in Moonstone (the liquid version) and it was seriously glowy & gorgeous. I've also mixed this with a few of my matte blushes as a topper to give a little something extra, and i'm really enjoying it. 

Overall, L'Oreal did really well with this one. I've yet to try the Maybeline competitor (the contour looks a bit orangey and warm so i'm a tad bit nervous), but I think the Infallible Pro-Contour will be the standout for me.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: H&M DOES BEAUTY & A NARS TREAT
item.content:encoded:
As many of you may know, H&M has released their own line of beauty products! While this is exciting for a few reasons, I’m most excited to see if the quality compares to that of Top Shop makeup. I don’t have a topshop nearby, so another brand who’s very on-trend producing quality, affordable beauty products is a dream. 

I went to my local store and picked up a few items. Now, my local H&M happens to be located in a mall, near a Nordstrom. So, as you probably guessed from the title, I did a tiny bit of shopping there as well & picked up a little something i’ve been eying for a very long time. 

From the H&M range (which I was very impressed with how many product they’ve brought out), I picked up an eyeliner, blush, lipstick, and an eye brush. 

Overall, I’m pleased with my selections. The lipstick is by far the standout for me. I selected Cream Chestnut, a browny-nude with a slightly glossy finish. It’s very moisturizing and comfortable to wear, and the color is spot on what I was looking for in a fall nude. They had a huge color selection for their lipsticks, so i’m sure i’ll be checking out a few more shades. 

I got the shade Wildlife in their eyeliner pencil. (which I can't seem to locate the color online, but i'm sure the other colors are amazing as well!)  It’s an olive green shade with a gorgeous but subtle gold shimmer running through it. I’ve been wearing this on it’s own to create a different take on the cate eye. It’s so creamy but does last pretty well also. 

The blush I picked up is in the shade Cameo Pink. Admittedly, it’s a pretty similar color to a handful of other blushes I own. Nonetheless, it’s a beautiful muted dusty pink that gives the perfect flush. It’s not the most long wearing, but for the price tag I really like the formula. 

Last but not least, I got their new crease brush. I’m of the mindset that a gal can always use another fluffy crease brush. This one turned out to be a bit more tapered and not the softest, but it works really well for placing and building up color in the crease. 

Onto the little Nars bit that snuck into my hands: the eyeshadow duo in Isolde. Need I even say more? This beautiful pair have been popular in the beauty world for a long time now, and i’m not sure what took me so long to add it to my collection. The hype here is spot on—these two shades are all kinds of shimmery gold & copper, warm-toned goodness. The formula is amazing as always with Nars, and i’ve been wearing these kind of non stop since I brought it home. Next i’ve got my eyes on their dual Intensity eyeshadows in the shades Himalia and Subra. 

Have you picked up any new product launches lately? Or anything you’ve been dying to get your hands on?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: FACE MASKS TO TRY
item.content:encoded:
Since I have rather sensitive, sometimes moody, stressed skin—I am careful with the products I choose to test out. This often leads me to raid the travel section or the little isle of doom that leads one up to the register at stores like Ulta and Sephora. Good skincare is expensive. While this is one area which i'll never feel bad investing in, I still shy away from throwing down the cash before I know how my skin is going to get along with a product. 

If you're not close to an Ulta or Sephora, turning to sephora.com is a great option. They often pull together collections of the sample size products into different "Sephora Favorites". They'll do these for many different types of products: fragrance, eyeliners, mascaras, lipsticks, etc. They range in price from about $25-$100, depending on how many products are included. It's a great way to try new brands, as well! 
While the two products I'm talking about today didn't come from one of these, I wanted to bring this up since it's such a great deal! 

Today i'm going to hit on two great face masks i've tried lately, each for a different purpose: 

The Origins Clear Improvements mask is a charcoal mask, for purifying the skin. The goal of this mask is to draw out all of the impurities in the pores. Since it is a charcoal mask, you apply a layer all over the face and then once it's dried, you can take it off. I find this nice since it's usually a rather short amount of time—ten, maybe 20 mins. I do love a good pamper, but I often find that I don't really get around to it until about 10:00 at night and by that time, i'm just trying to get to bed ASAP. The mask really is wonderful. It's one of those tricky ones that can make you break out a bit after using it, but this is just because it's pulled all impurities to the surface, so they can get out! It's about a deep clear-out, so this can happen with these types of products. You can't beat the clean feeling after using this mask! 

The REN Glycol Lactic Radiance Renewal Mask is a good one to follow a few days to a week after that Origins mask. This mask is, as the name would suggest, aimed at brightening the complexion. There's a few natural acids in the mask to exfoliate, brighten and plump up the skin. It's helped to break down discoloration or hyper pigmentation, and really make my skin look healthy! This is another quick mask—ten minutes! Win.

There you have it! Two masks i'd recommend trying; and a little bit about how I like to try out new products. 

Have you tried any skincare products recently that are worth checking out?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: SUNSET EYES WITH NAKED 2
item.content:encoded:
Lately i've really been getting back into my Urban Decay Naked 2 palette. It has such a great selection of colors, a mix of warm and cool tones, a load of shimmery shades and a few great mattes. In playing around, I came up with a look that Nick so kindly says "looks like sunsets on your eyes". I'll take it.

Here’s how I got this look: 
As a base, I used the Chanel stylo eyeshadow in Laurier Rose. (full review here) This is a long-lasting cream shadow stick in a bright rosy-pink color, so it’s a perfect base for this look. I take this all over the lid and blend out, so it should be a nice gradient into the crease. 

Next, take the darkest color in this look, Chopper from the Naked 2 palette, on a crease brush and blend into the crease. 

Then, taking Half Baked from Naked 2 on a flatter eyeshadow brush, apply this color on the outer half of the lid, below where you applied Chopper. You can use the brush you used to apply Chopper to blend the edges of these two shades together.

Lastly, use the color Bootycall, where despite the name this is my most used shade in the palette (can ya tell?)—it’s just the perfect brow & inner corner highlight for my skin tone! I’m still sad they haven’t brought this color out in a single pan. Anyways, with Bootycall, take this on the inner corner of your eye, blending it up onto the lid but not too far. Then, use it as the brow highlight as well. 

Taking a very fluffy crease brush, I use the Sonia Kashuk 109, blend out the edges of everything to make it a bit softer. To finish off the look I take a bit of chopper on a smaller brush and run it along the lower lash line, then slap on some mascara. I've started using (and loving) the Maybeline Lash Sensational mascara in black, it gives some serious oomph and length, and separates the lashes nicely. And bonus! it’s got a pinky-metallic packaging. Ahh the little things. 

Well, there you have it! I think this is a great look for any occasion. I’ve worn it to events, nights out, etc. It’s a nice twist on the standard nighttime smoky-eye without being too dark. 

Pair this with a peachy blush and a nude lip to really polish it off!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: EYE'S READY FOR FALL
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to makeup looks for specific seasons, I tend to think those rules can and should be broken. If you want to wear a bold, dark lip in the summer, or a really light coverage & glowy look in the winter—why not? You do you, my friend. 

Lately, however, i’ve been getting really into cooler, darker tones in both my clothing and makeup. Breaking back into my olive green sweaters and deep purple eyeshadows. There’s no doubt this is a product of the changing seasons. Fall has always been my favorite, and I am extremely sad that Cincinnati fall’s seem to be getting shorter and shorter. (we’re looking at you, climate change) 

While i’m totally into these deeper shades on my lids (and the lips, if we’re being honest) once again, I have been pairing them with some more “summer appropriate” colors to help it be more of a transitional look. 

To achieve this, i’m back to being obsessed with my MAC Burgundy Times Nine palette. If you haven’t seen the MAC "Times Nine" range you’re seriously missing out. (I believe they're exclusively sold from Nordstrom, along with a few other special MAC palettes) They have them in a few different color collections, and they’re only $40. Let me say that again: Forty. Dollars. Now, these pans are a little smaller than the full-size MAC shadows we’re all used to, but I still think it’s an amazing deal—there's nine shadows in there, people! 


When I purchased this I didn’t think I’d get any use out of the shimmery gold color in the top left called Gold Lust. As the summer came through, let me tell you, it’s my most used shadow in the palette. You can tell I’ve made a serious dent in it. It's a wonderful warm, truly golden hue that looks so beautifully beachy. It does have a pretty chunky glitter, and I definitely recommend a primer or eyeshadow base underneath. In the Summer,  I’d let it stand alone all over the lid and a little on the lower lash line, tons of mascara & done. Now, as it gets cooler, this is where the other shades in this palette come into play. Lately, i’ve been starting with that same summery look, but now adding some of Haux (bottom row; far left), medium-toned matte plum color, through the crease & Sketch (bottom row; far right), a deep plum, in the outer-v. I'll always use a clean, fluffy brush at the end to blend out any harsh lines. 

From there, I’m a creature of habit. Slapping on a couple (or 5) coats of mascara (currently addicted to the L’Oreal Telescopic Carbon Black) and that’s my almost fall eye look sorted.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: THIS YEAR IN BOOKS: WHAT I'VE READ SO FAR
item.content:encoded:
Hey-o! 

Coming at ya with some thoughts on books I’ve read recently. I made a goal of reading 20 books this year, and for the first three months I was rocking through 2 books a month, thinking I would exceed my goal by December. Ha! April came, things have gotten busy again with wedding planning, and I’ve not managed to make it through a single book in the last 30 days.

That being said, i’m still chugging along. I’m currently reading The F Word by Lily Pebbles and Uncommon Type by Tom Hanks (he reads the audiobook himself and it’s just amazing.), and enjoying both albeit how slow i’m moving. But today I wanted to share a bit about what i’ve read so far this year, my thoughts on the books, and if I’d recommend them! I track all of my reads on GoodReads, come follow along, I love adding new friends on there to see what others are reading! 

I’ve read a few space themed books, because i’m that kind of nerd: 
Space Chronicles by Neil DeGrasse Tyson
I think knowing the author of this book can give you a clue into what it’s like! He’s a genius, and I love adding his books into my TBR lists now and again. This one takes a look back where the USA has been in terms of space exploration, where we are now, and what may lie in the future. I definitely enjoyed it, but it might not be that gripping to those who aren’t interested the topic. 

Artemis by Andy Weir
Let me start by telling you that Rosario Dawson reads the audiobook for this, and it. is. great. I’ve gotten really into audiobooks this year, either listening on Audible or Scribd. This was a much-anticipated second book by Andy Weir, who wrote The Martain (another book I am a super-fan of). I loved the world Weir created, the spunky main character, and all the action of this plot. Like The Martian, this is about living in space. Unlike The Martian, this book is set in the future when humans are actually living in space. Well, the moon, to be exact. I got through this book so quickly, it hooked me from the start! 
I highly suggest this read! 

The Long Way To A Small Angry Planet by Becky Chambers
I heard of this book in a video Books and Quills did around space books a while back. It’s a YA pick which is out of my norm, but I have to say I enjoyed it very much! It’s about an unlikely crew living in space, taking jobs to cut new routes through space. That’s probably a terrible explanation (GoodReads does a much better job), but I think this books really teaches the lesson to not judge people based on where they’ve come from, and especially not by the ways in which they may be different from you. I loved that the author included such detailed back stories for all of the characters and you really felt like you were on the Wayfarer with the crew. 
I recommend if you grew up watching Star Trek and still feel nostalgic about it! 

A popular read, which normally wouldn’t fall into my hands:
Annihilation by Jeff VanderMeer
This guy was a weird one. It’s short, and I read it in just two sittings. I definitely found myself always wanting to get to the next page. It was weird, that’s for sure. My friends and I do a monthly book club where this was a book we tackled. I will say, it frustrated many people. There are so many questions, loose ends, twists and turns. I won’t even kid you by saying the ending provides any closure. Now, it is the first in a three-book series, so you probably shouldn’t jump into this hoping for it to be a neat little package anyhow. That being said, I’m still unsure on if i’ll read the other two books. I’m kind of okay with how this ended. I’m okay with not knowing the answers to my many questions along the way. I’m not sure if I recommend this book, honestly. I can say with confidence that this is far different from the film with the same name. It actually quite frustrates me because I noticed they produced a movie-cover paperback. But just from watching the trailer for the film after reading the book, they are so different. Choose your own adventure on this one, folks. 

A book I think everyone should read:
Enlightenment Now by Steven Pinker
I have so many thoughts about this piece of work that there’s no way I could get them all into a coherent blurb in this post for you. This is about life and the world we live in. It’s about the progress we’ve made as a human race—and how we often times spend the majority of our lives concentrating on the bad, on what’s wrong in the world, and completely ignore the good. Pinker compels you to for goodness sake please look at the actual data pertaining to current events and issues before just letting the major news stations tell you what to think. Do I agree with every bit of this book or the perspective it takes? No. Did it make me stop and really think about stuff? Yes. It was so enlightening to me—not to get cheesy with the title. Most importantly I think this can be bi-partisan. Steven Pinker is who he is, and at times he can be quite polarizing, but he’s really just imploring you to do your own research and try to come to your own conclusions. I recommend this to anyone and everyone. I will warn: it’s a doozy. Almost 600 pages, and the audio book is nearly 30 hours long. However, worth it in my opinion.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: TWO BOOKS YOU SHOULD READ RIGHT NOW
item.content:encoded:
When racking my brain on what to write about to get my back into blogging, I thought of how I've always wanted to talk more about books on here. So, saving you having to read any more rambling.. here's two books I think you should pick up, if you're interested! 

Everything I Never Told you, Celeste Ng

This book was not one I expected to like. It was a book-club pick off the NYT bestsellers list, which isn’t usually my go-to. I have a hard time with fiction. Not because it isn’t wonderful writing, because it is. Mostly I just tend to gravitate toward true stories and books on certain topics. Alas, I gave this book a shot and I’m glad I did! There’s a bit of (more recent) American history thrown in with some real family drama. The characters in this book seem like they should have had such normal lives, and in some ways they did. It’s a perfect quick summer read! 

Bloom: Navigating Life And Style, Estee Lalonde

I’ve had this since it came out, pre-ordered, in fact. I devoured the book in two sittings, and I’ve read it another time since then! I have been a long-time follower of estee lalonde, the one of a kind gal behind this book, so it was a no-brainer that i’d love it! She talks you through so many of her experiences and shares advice based on them, but it’s in no way telling you how to live your life. As you’re reading you can tell the amount of thought and energy that went into every page. It’s an uplifting read and also helps remind me that nobody is perfect, and that’s what makes us all so great. 

Rock on, Estee! 

What have you been reading lately?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: VACATION READING LIST
item.content:encoded:
Vacation is so close, guys! This Saturday we'll be jetting off to Portugal. Naturally, I had to get together a reading list for the trip, and I thought it would be fun to share it with you! 

There is one teensy downside to the trip, and that's the long layovers we'll have on the journey. Since we'll have some serious time to kill in the airports both on the way there and on the way back, my list is a bit longer than what i'd normally select for a trip like this. Eight books is quite ambitious, no doubt. But, with a few of these being audio books, I think i'll actually make quite the dent in this selection! 

Brooklyn: 
What goodreads says: "Eilis Lacey has come of age in small-town Ireland in the hard years following World War Two. When an Irish priest from Brooklyn offers to sponsor Eilis in America -- to live and work in a Brooklyn neighborhood "just like Ireland" -- she decides she must go, leaving her fragile mother and her charismatic sister behind."

Why I want to read it: I have heard so many things about this! I have yet to see the film as I was waiting to read the book. Can't wait to see what all the fuss is about! 

The Girl With The Lower Back Tattoo:
What goodreads says: "The Emmy Award-winning comedian, actress, writer, and star of Inside Amy Schumer and the acclaimed film Trainwreck has taken the entertainment world by storm with her winning blend of smart, satirical humor. Now, Amy Schumer has written a refreshingly candid and uproariously funny collection of (extremely) personal and observational essays." 

Why I want to read it: Do I even need to explain this one? Amy. Schumer. 

How to Start a Fire:
What goodreads says: "From a bestselling writer, a story of unexpected friendship-three women thrown together in college who grow to adulthood united and divided by secrets, lies, and a single night that shaped all of them"

Why I want to read it: Doesn't that just sound intriguing? I love a good story that has some scandal, and I think this read will deliver that! 

Aristotle and Dante Discover The Secrets of the Universe:
What goodreads says: "Aristotle is an angry teen with a brother in prison. Dante is a know-it-all who has an unusual way of looking at the world. When the two meet at the swimming pool, they seem to have nothing in common. But as the loners start spending time together, they discover that they share a special friendship—the kind that changes lives and lasts a lifetime."

Why I want to read it:  I'm always on the hunt for a good YA novel, and this sounded like an interesting and fun take on an unusual pair becoming great friends. I also heard the writing was beautiful so I had to add it to the list!

Vinegar Girl:
What goodreads says: "Kate Battista feels stuck. How did she end up running house and home for her eccentric scientist father and uppity, pretty younger sister Bunny? Plus, she’s always in trouble at work – her pre-school charges adore her, but their parents don’t always appreciate her unusual opinions and forthright manner.  "

Why I want to read it: I'm pretty excited by all of these classic retellings that are coming about. I love to see how the same themes are applied to modern day life. Most of the time, it makes me appreciate the original even more!  

How to Build a Girl: 
What goodreads says: "What do you do in your teenage years when you realize what your parents taught you wasn’t enough? You must go out and find books and poetry and pop songs and bad heroes—and build yourself."

Why I want to read it: This book has caught a ton of attention since it came out, and I've had my eye on it for a while. I'm eager to see how it turns out! 

Silver Linings Playbook:
What goodreads says: "Meet Pat. Pat has a theory: his life is a movie produced by God. And his God-given mission is to become physically fit and emotionally literate, whereupon God will ensure a happy ending for him -- the return of his estranged wife Nikki."

Why I want to read it: So I haven't read this or seen the movie. I know, I know. It's a beloved story. That's why I'm making a point to read it while away! I think i'll really enjoy this, although I have a feeling it's going to pull on those ole heart strings. 

Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance:
What goodreads says: "One of the most important & influential books written in the past half-century, Robert M. Pirsig's Zen & the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance is a powerfully moving & penetrating examination of how we live, a breathtaking meditation on how to live better. Here is the book that transformed a generation, an unforgettable narration of a summer motorcycle trip across America's Northwest, undertaken by a father & his young son."

Why I want to read it: Nick has been suggesting this book to me basically since the day we met. In an effort to prove I listen to him, I'll be getting into this one! (I also am sure I will like it, so it's not all about Nick :) )

I am planning to do a wrap up style post on this list after the vacation so you can know how much I got through and what my final thoughts on the books are!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: USEFUL COFFEE TABLE BOOKS
item.content:encoded:
Let's face it, coffee table books are addicting. They look pretty, they're a great addition to the style of your home, and they can really show off the personality and interests of whoever lives in the space. But, do you ever find yourself shelling out the cash on these books and then once you get them home you don't actually read them? C'mon, I know I'm not the only one guilty of this. Sometimes we forget that these books have amazing stories, information, and photos residing within them. There are two books in my collection that stand out to me, as these are ones whose covers i'm in love with, but I also love what's inside. 

The first one is a cookbook, Sunday Suppers. This was a gift I received last Christmas, and was quite fitting as I have a goal this year to try out one new recipe each week. The style of this one is basically me, in a book. I love the covers, the pages, and the photography. Some of the recipes are a little on the advanced side, but I've still made use of a few! You may or may not know my addiction to Mexican food...okay so it's really just tacos and guac. This book has a whole section devoted to the Taqueria—dreams come true. The book is separated out by time of day and/or an event such as a holiday, so you can do breakfast, lunch, and dinner all from the same cookbook! 

The next, hits my heart pretty hard. Another perfectly fitting gift for me. I've always had a thing for flowers, but I was recently inspired to learn more about them. The women in my family have always known seemingly all there is to know about plants and flowers. My grandmother and mom can name just about any plant they see. I always took this for granted until I wanted to get plants for my new home. I, of course, called on my mom to help me pick, but I wanted to learn for myself as well! So, this book, The Flower Workshop, along with some others is helping me do that! It's broken up by colors, type of flower, or specific elements of arrangements. It even has recipes for each featured arrangement, so you could take it to your local nursery and get exactly what's needed to recreate them! The author of this book, Ariella Chezar, is very talented in the floral industry, she actually holds these Flower Workshops (the inspiration for the book) in person! 

Are there any coffee table books you love to actually read? Are there any I should get my hands on?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: SPRING READING LIST
item.content:encoded:
Ever since I finished my reading goal from my 30 before 25 list, I’ve been seriously slacking in the reading department. So, I wanted to start putting together seasonal reading lists of books that I really want to set out to read that season. Now, there will likely (hopefully) be more than this, but this list is a collection of books I’ve been meaning to read.

(The description of each book is pulled from goodreads.com, the few sentences after are my own thoughts on why i’d like to read the book!)

Sous Chef—In this urgent and unique book, chef Michael Gibney uses twenty-four hours to animate the intricate camaraderie and culinary choreography in an upscale New York restaurant kitchen. Here readers will find all the details, in rapid-fire succession, of what it takes to deliver an exceptional plate of food—the journey to excellence by way of exhaustion.
This caught my eye months ago as a book that Nick would like, since we’re both fascinated by cooking and the food industry, and he’s really into routines. I picked it up for him and he said it was a great read, so i’ve been eying it up ever since. I’ve not made the time to read it, so i’m going to do that now!
(buy here)

A Most Wanted Man—A half-starved young Russian man in a long black overcoat is smuggled into Hamburg at dead of night. He has an improbable amount of cash secreted in a purse around his neck. He is a devout Muslim. Or is he?
I’ve heard enough about this story when the movie came out, mostly because of it’s stellar cast LINK. But, when I can, I like to read the book first if the movie is an adaptation. I think this will be an exciting read!
(buy here)

It’s What I Do—War photographer Lynsey Addario’s memoir It’s What I Do is the story of how the relentless pursuit of truth, in virtually every major theater of war in the twenty-first century, has shaped her life. What she does, with clarity, beauty, and candor, is to document, often in their most extreme moments, the complex lives of others. It’s her work, but it’s much more than that: it’s her singular calling.
The obvious draw for me here is my love of photographs. But this book seems to also have other aspects I enjoy: a memoir style story of someone following what they’ve realized is their calling to do something that makes the world better.
(buy here)

Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close—Nine-year-old Oskar Schell is an inventor, amateur entomologist, Francophile, letter writer, pacifist, natural historian, percussionist, romantic, Great Explorer, jeweller, detective, vegan, and collector of butterflies. When his father is killed in the September 11th attacks on the World Trade Centre, Oskar sets out to solve the mystery of a key he discovers in his father's closet.
I’ve got a head start on this one as it’s this month’s pick for a book club i’m in! I have heard so many good things about Oskar’s journey and the beautiful way it’s written. Another one I am going to wait to see the film version of until I complete the book.
(buy here)

Stumbling on Happiness—In this brilliant, witty, and accessible book, renowned Harvard psychologist Daniel Gilbert describes the foibles of imagination and illusions of foresight that cause each of us to misconceive our tomorrows and misestimate our satisfactions.
This comes on recommendation from countless people. As someone who enjoys learning about the human brain and how the science of it all plays into our personalities and emotions, I’m sure this book will live up to the hype.
(buy here)

I think i’ll be writing more about books here, as I really love reading and want to make it more of a constant in my daily routine.

Do you have any book recommendations?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: COLLECTING CLASSICS
item.content:encoded:
Like many other people, I am one who really enjoys a good book. I like to be immersed in a world that is not my own, learn more about who people are and how they function, and find characters I can really root for. 

Many of my favorite books have been around for quite some time. I will pick up a Fitzgerald, Hemingway, or Austen before looking at any new read that’s hit the NYT Bestsellers list. This led me to start up a hobby I wasn’t entirely sure was there until it was pointed out to me—I have a thing for collecting different editions of my favorite books. I am drawn in to cover art I’ve not seen before, Penguin does some of my favorites and they're always coming out with new collections to please the eye of classic readers! Now, I still have the same ratty copies of my favorites that I’ve had since the beginning, but I do stay on the lookout for new editions to add to my collection. 

Now that my boyfriend has pointed this habit of collecting to me, I think it's something i'll try to do more consciously. I've spoken previously about my love for Pride and Prejudice, and I'm definitely interested in a few more editions of it that i've seen around, and there's always those ever so dreamy editions of a few Fitzgerald novels. 

If you come to my home, you'll find books everywhere. These comes from both of us—we're book hoarders. We've got large bookshelves and piles on every open surface. I love to decorate with stacks of books, and I do rotate them around every now and again. I just feel more comfortable with books around, you really can't trust people who don't have any laying around their home—am I right?! :) 

What do you like to collect?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: 30 BEFORE 30 REVEAL
item.content:encoded:
My next goal list is here! 

As mentioned in my birthday reflection post from last week, I wanted to continue having a list of things i'd like to experience and accomplish over the next 5 years. I decided to keep it at 30, because currently that number feels right, and who doesn't think 30 before 30 sounds good?

An important point I want to hammer home with these lists: if you're going to make one, make sure it's 100% about you. That doesn't mean it can't include other people, mine does! I love the people in my life and I want to make a point to experience great things with them. But, I want to do all of these things for myself as well. When creating your list take the time to be selfish! Put yourself first. You should have fun with this, and you can't have as much fun if you aren't excited by the possibility of completing each item. 

I don't have any lofty wisdom to give you on creating a goal list like these, except to think of things that will bring you joy. I use these to instill habits, push myself out of my comfort zone, and to remind myself of things I don't want to let slip through the cracks. I also use it to keep track of some smaller things I'd like to learn or experience. It was an item on my last list that led me to really commit to putting time into this blog. I wanted to post on the blog more frequently, so I put it on my list, and I have no doubt it was a much-needed kick in the rear. 

One final note: remember these aren't set in stone. No one is grading you. If you create your list and a year later find there's something on it which you're no longer interested in—replace it. You're holding yourself accountable, but you're not setting concrete restraints. 

Check out my 30 before 30 here! 

Do you have a list of goals similar to this? I'd love to see them!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: TWENTY FIVE
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday was my twenty-fifth birthday. Wowza! I used to think 25 was so old. I remember when my oldest cousin was this age, and I thought she was so cool and independent. (She still is, btw). I just never imagined this day would come back then! 

You always have visions while growing up about what being an “adult” would be like. I can tell you, I couldn’t have predicted this at all. 

I’m 25. I have a loving and fulfilling relationship, an amazing dog, a career I can work hard at, a family who’s there for me always, and amazing friends. These people all chose to gather with me and celebrate this milestone with me, and I was unable to stop from getting a bit sappy. There’s so much going on in the world today. It’s an ugly, terrifying place in some respects. But in others, it’s bright and full of potential. I don’t force myself to step back and look at it all often enough, I don’t think anyone does. 

At this point in my life there are challenges, but they’re nothing I can’t handle—nothing that i’m not excited to face head-on. I’ve travelled, read, danced, cried, loved, and laughed through 25 years of life, and for that I am grateful. 

I wanted to spend time today addressing my 30 before 25 list. As you may know, I was able to cross a good amount off of that list, but, I didn’t complete it—yet. Here’s the thing about this list. I set out with high hopes. If you check it out, you’ll see I created it when I graduated college. I was 21 then. Needless to say, goals change! I did amend the list slightly as time went on, but there were some things on there that I didn’t get to. Some I should have, but some I feel okay about missing. 

Will I create another list? Yes. Will it likely have some items that are migrated from the old list? Yes. 

Here’s a look at what I completed: 

Attend a music festival (Midpoint Music Festival, October 2014)
Move into my own apartment (March 2014)
Land a job I enjoy and take pride in (January 2014)
Travel to France (October 2014)
Write for the blog twice a week (with a one month benchmark to create the habit) (March + April 2016)
Contribute writing to another blog (The Ahalogy blog; multiple)
Create a manageable workout regimen that makes me feel great. (began training with Jill in Dec. 2014)
Grow my hair out to mid-back length (it's about there, i'd say! April 2015) (and I just cut it off! HA! July, 2016)
Get a dog ([Fitz came home in August 2015!)
Visit NYC (April 2014)
Clean out closet and donate what I don't keep (Cut clothing in half in Jan. 2014) 
Read 30 new books
Make spaghetti squash (April 2015—NO idea what took me so long!)
Get a nice camera and put more time into taking photos—dreaming of the Olympus Pen E-PL7 (JULY 2015, Olympus Pen E-PL7 Purchased!)
Visit San Fransisco (May 2014) 
Lead a major project start to finish (work) (Brand Voice and Tone Guide, Jan. 2014)
Visit Harry Potter World at Universal Studios (Went with my mom in Oct. 2015!)

And, what I didn’t: 

Buy a new (personal) apple computer
Purchase the top 10 items on my high-end beauty wishlist
Visit Seattle
Take Nick to Denver
See Dave Matthews Band at the Gorge
Create my dream home office space
Take my mom to Europe or Belize
Read every Hemingway novel (The Old Man and The Sea, The Sun Also Rises,)
Run a 10k
Create a "Before I Die..." wall in Cincinnati and maintain it for a month.

There are some things on there that were definitely attainable, but in a few instances I let life take me different directions. I feel great about what I did accomplish and how I was able to use this list to guide where I spent my time (and funds) through the last four years. 

I’m hoping to my next list out very soon. And I think i’ll be extending this one to 30. 30? Weird. 
I’m excited to reveal that once it’s all completed!

Cheers my friends, to 25 great years past and many more to come! 

PS—Stay tuned for a photo diary post from my birthday celebrations coming this week! I had an amazing time with some of my best friends and family. I couldn't be more thankful for the people I have in my life, they make it all worth it!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WEEKLY MUSINGS VOL 1
item.content:encoded:
I wanted to do a wrap-up style post, but locking into a weekly cadence seemed like I could end up scraping around for things to talk about when I had a rather boring week. Which, let’s be honest, happens quite often. So, the cadence for this series will be much more broad, and i’m thinking at least once a month will be good, or maybe more if there’s a lot going on.
I want this series to be more about what's on my mind in the given time, rather than always have a specific topic. I’d like to share articles I happened upon that I think are worth a read, books i’ve finished or started, my opinion on current events, and other sources of inspiration for my life and my work.

To read: If your workplace uses any sort of instant messaging software for communication, I think you’ll enjoy this article. While it’s a longer read, there are some excellent points on how this can actually diminish the productivity of employees if used poorly—definitely a different perspective than most out there on the topic!

Also, this book has given me a need to bring more blooms into my life. I have a bit of space for planters at the new house, so I'm excited to delve into the world of gardening a bit. Expect photos and posts to come this spring + summer!

To view: This interior.  Major swoon. The bright whites and mixes of woods. It’s so dreamy.

To try: This falafel recipe. I made this on sunday to have for my lunches this week, and I definitely snuck one right after they were done—so yummy! Now, they didn’t come out as pretty as I’d hoped, but luckily they taste the same no matter the shape!

To add to the wish list: This beautiful piece of makeup art. I have a feeling I won’t be able to hold out too long on this one. I mean, would ya look at it?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: GREEN THUMB
item.content:encoded:
Is anyone else becoming quickly obsessed with greenery in their home? I know, obviously, house plants have been a thing for a very long time. I’ve never been good at keeping them alive to be honest. I have a few succulents that are going strong and i’m quite proud of that!
I’ve always liked having fresh flowers, but we all know how pricy that can get. Lately, though, i’ve been becoming much more interested in flowers, flower arrangements, and greenery. I’m seeing a trip to the local nursery in my future…
We have a move coming up, which is quite exciting for many reasons (hello, redecorating!). But one of the things i’m most excited about is many more spaces to keep plants.
First of all, I am a huge supporter of having a mixture of both real and faux plants. Ikea has some really nice faux greens that I really like scattering around my home. There’s just so much to be said about having the greenery be your pop of color! Since I keep a mostly monochromatic home, the plants can really stand out and bring life to the room.

Something we’re really excited to do in the new home is try out a version of a living wall. We won’t do a super busy or filled wall, since our rooms aren’t that big and we don’t want to overwhelm a space, but we’re definitely going to do something similar. I really like this idea:

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="564.0"] image via [/caption] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="600.0"] image via [/caption]

I also really enjoy smaller installments, like this:
 

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="540.0"] image via [/caption]

I’m planning on increasing my single-potted plant collection, but also looking into making a terrarium! I think these are such a fun way to do something different and incorporate plants. There are so many different takes on how to make these so you can try out what you find the most interesting. This tutorial really caught my eye. totally doable. 

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="550.0"] image via [/caption]

 

How do you like to incorporate greenery into your space?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: INTERIOR INSPIRATION: HOME OFFICE
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been wanting to make my dream home office space for a long time now. I even have it as a goal on my 30 before 25 list! 
Last year, I bought a vanity table to help store my makeup collection as well as serve as a workspace for when I am working from home. While this table has worked up until this point, it’s gotten rather messy, and I’ve noticed some things I don’t love about it, like it’s size and the inability to cross my legs while sitting at it. I know that might sound crazy, but it’s super important to me. I find that I get really stiff legs and knees if I can't move them around by crossing and uncrossing while i'm working. It’s like the shoulder test with handbags, ya know? If I can’t cross my legs comfortably while sitting at a desk, it won’t work out for me over any long period of time. Because of this, I haven’t been using this vanity for working, which means I really only sit there for about 20 mins each day.

Here's my current set up:

I also realized quickly that while white wood is bright and pretty, I don’t really enjoy it. I much prefer natural wood colors as they don’t show wear as quickly. All of this has led me back to the hunt for a great desk. I’ve gone back and forth on if I want built in storage or something on the side, and I think i’ve settled on supplemental storage. While it would be nice to have drawers for my daily makeup, I’m just not finding something that really fits the bill with that requirement. I think i’ve honed in on the desk I’d like—surprise it’s IKEA—and the storage i’d like to go with it

Before I make any purchases, though, i’m really torture testing the whole picture as best I can. I want to make sure i’m not going to be unhappy with my pieces a year from now. I’m envisioning natural wood, with mixes of white, grey, black, and pops of metallic.

Here's my inspiration for redoing my workspace: 

Image 1, 2, 3 

 

Where do you get inspiration for decorating your space?

item.title: SAVING MEMORIES WITH A SCRAPBOOKING ALTERNATIVE
item.content:encoded:
When I was a kid, I went through my scrapbooking phase as I think most gals do. (and guys, you probably did this, or something similar, too!) I bought the big book, patterned background pages, sicker sets, and gel pens. I had my mom take me to get prints of all my photos, and I went to town. I stuck at it for a short while, but as I grew up my tastes changed and I started to dislike my (full of stars and hearts) cover design. I had some great memories from making the book to go along with those inside. 

As I got older I noticed myself keeping things. Random things, really, but they reminded me of an event that I wanted to be able to look back on. There were many different forms of this practice. I had an envelope, a box, a file folder. I kept a lot of things. 

A while back, sheesh, probably six or seven years ago now, I really cut back what I saved. It came down to one pretty small item that I was interested in holding onto: tickets. I have tickets from concerts, sporting events, museums, plays. I have my registration numbers from running 5k’s, movie tickets, speaking event credentials, and plane tickets. I was rooting around for something to keep them in and stumbled upon mason jar my mom had once kept her friend’s homemade salsa in. And there was it was born—my memory jar. 

As I began to travel more, I saved things like a napkin from a cafe in Paris and the bag our pastries came in at a bakery in Aix en Provence. I even have the key to the first place I lived with Nick, and the tracing paper from my first tattoo which was for my grandma. I now look for little objects that are about the size of a typical ticket, or that can be folded, at most events I attend. Those that know me can probably tell you about a time where I asked to swap tickets with them, as theirs was in better shape than mine (usually after a rainy concert at cincy’s big outdoor music venue—it always rains at the DMB show every year). 

I found this is the perfect way for me to keep track of memories that I’ll never forget, but might not get to think about as much as I’d like. I had the best time pulling everything out of the jar to shoot these photos, everything came rushing back. I laughed and teared up looking at all of my memories. It was everything I wanted the jar to be. 

I imagine one day i’ll need a bigger jar, or even multiples, as I don’t plan to stop saving these things. For now, i’ll just keep stuffing this one full until it won’t take any more. 

Do you save little things like this? Do you have a system of your own? I’d love to hear about it!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WHEN ADULTING GETS THE BEST OF YOU
item.content:encoded:
It’s no secret that I haven’t been posting as much as I was. I was on quite the roll with two posts a week, and my editorial calendar was all pretty and neat. Then, life happened. Work got busier, I got stressed and tired. But that's no excuse, is it? Since when is it acceptable to let the hustle and bustle of everyday adulting get in the way of your passions? It's not. 

The issue when you work long days on a computer and being a blogger on the side is that you may get home from your day job wanting to do anything besides continue to hunch over your computer. What I should have done, but didn’t do, was get outside. Take my camera and just walk around. Excursions like that, where I don’t really have an agenda yet I just set out to observe, are when I get some of my best shots and find inspiration to write. 

I could continue give you a bunch of excuses to justify it, but it’s not worth it. Falling off schedule to me is more than letting down readers to me, it’s letting down myself! I set out a goal for myself to post consistently because I know, that if I want to grow from five readers (hi Nick, Alexa, Mom, Josh, and Tori 😃 ), to much more than that—consistency is a key factor! 

There’s no way around the fact that right now, I have a full time job. Not to mention that it’s at a startup, which tends to mean it’s even a bit more than what pops in your head when you think of “full time”. 

But, I’m getting back on track. I found that using this blog as my outlet really helped me mentally and allowed me to express myself in a way I don’t anywhere else. It’s pretty liberating to type up your thoughts and put them out there without needing rounds of editing and approval first. (can you tell I also write as part of my day job? 😉 )

Creative outlets, whatever they may be and no matter your level of talent, are essential to balance in life. No one can be all work all the time. So here I am, renewing my promise to myself and getting back on track. Tuesday's and Friday's—expect a new post on the The Desk of Susan! 

 Also, I hope you enjoyed looking through some outtakes from my first attempt at getting Nick to take some photos of/for me, I felt they are appropriate for this post, to remind me that this is a work in progress, and it doesn't happen overnight. 
Note: they're outtakes because I could not get comfortable, not because Nick doesn't take good photos! Because he does. Here's proof.
