item.title: 6 THINGS TO DO WITH A FREE SPRING WEEKNIGHT
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024.0"]   Image via  New Darlings [/caption]

So you’re a work-a-holic and decided to shut the screen for one night? Or, you had rad plans but they’ve been rescheduled? Did you have a long day at work and now you need a pick me up?

Before you resort to trolling Pinterest or binging on Netflix for the evening (although both are appealing), consider one of these five activities to make the most of your clear schedule:

1. See an outdoor movie

Whether it’s a drive-in theatre or some other set up, it’s great activity to enjoy the warmer weather while relaxing and catching a film! You can usually find that these types of set ups are playing classics or older films that you haven’t seen—or already love!

2. Drinks on a patio

Does this even need an explanation? If you don’t have outdoor space of your own (or even if you do) getting a seat on a patio with friends to have a casual post-work drink is the ultimate way to unwind on a weeknight.

3. Local sports game

If your city has any major or minor sports teams, see if there are any games going on! Baseball games are fun no matter your amount of emotional involvement with the sport or team, and sometimes you can even find pretty affordable tickets last minute on a weeknight!

4. Bike ride around town

In Cincinnati, we just got a public bike share system a year or two ago, but I know most bigger cities have had them for a while! It’s a great way to explore parts of your city you may not have had the chance to before, and you can go for as long or as little as you like!

5. Explore out a new park

Green space can clear any mind, i’m positive! I’m lucky enough to live close to a few of the more beautiful parks in my city, but I always love to branch out and see what new ones we can explore! They’re usually equipped with walking trails, and some even yield some great views. Big or small, there’s always an adventure to be had.

6. See free live music

In most places, you’ll find there’s live music being played either at various restaurants and bars, and there’s something about live music that just lifts you up! Lots of parks and amphitheaters will hold free summer concerts with local bands where anyone from the community can come enjoy the festivities.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: CHECK IN: MINDFULNESS MANTRA
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2448.0"] A fav coffee shop of mine in Nashville: Revelator [/caption]

It’s been about 2 months since I posted about my mantra for the year of 2016.
In case you missed this post where I introduced the idea, I adopted the phrase “Mindfulness is not bullshit” as my mantra for this year. I’d like to be more mindful of my mind, body, and overall health. I’ve been working so far on listening to my body much more than I ever used to. I’m eating better due planning my meals during the week, and really getting a sense for when certain foods make me feel good and energized vs. sluggish and tired.

As far as being more mindful of my brain and it’s workings, that’s still a work in progress. I’ve always been a bit of a stressed out gal, so it’s hard for me to find a good approach to this aspect. I still work on quick meditations now and then, but i’ve not found sitting for a long period of time very successful just yet. To be honest and risk sounding like a child, sitting still isn’t always that relaxing to me. To top off the stubborn vibe here, it’s sometimes hard to stick it out for 30 minutes when you’re realizing you’re not all that good at letting the thoughts drift away. I’m being open and honest here because I want people to realize that while this is somewhat of “the thing” to do right now, it’s not going to come easily for everyone.
So, I’m still working on it.

Where do I go from here?
I plan to do some studying. Of those who I think are great at this. There are people in my life who I know practice this idea of mindfulness, and I plan to see what I can learn from them. I also want to focus more on why I’m doing this as opposed to just doing it because I said I would. What brought me to this conclusion other than it sounding like the right/good thing to do.
Back to basics, people.

Are you tracking any goals for the year? How are they going?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: SO, YOU CAN'T SLEEP...
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="640.0"] image via Byrdie [/caption]

Neither can I. You know how there are things in life you accept you're just not good at? Well, sleep is one of those things for me. I've never been good at it. I was the 16 year old who couldn't sleep past 9:00 AM. Even if I stay up late, I'm still an early riser. Those close to me will say they think it's because my natural sleep pattern is to go to sleep early, and wake up with the sun. 

It's helped me at times, I praised this non-dependence on sleep when I took early morning classes in college. However, as an adult, it has at times become a point of contention for my sanity, so I'm trying to get better. For some of us, sleep is a learned skill, and that doesn't have to mean something is clinically wrong. 

Before I continue, let me say this this: I have not been diagnosed with insomnia or any other sleep disorder at this point. These are serious conditions that can (and should) be treated by a medical professional. I simply do not get good sleep. I don't stay asleep for long, and I'm a very light sleeper resulting in waking up many times a night.

All this being said, I've been working lately to achieve a better quality of sleep, and I'd like to share some things I've tried that help, and things that are silly and did not help. Also, I'll lastly touch on this awesome technology that's allowed me to know more definitively what worked. 

What worked: 

Aromatherapy "sleep” oil: My sweet Momma got me an aromatherapy oil named “Sleep” for my birthday this year. She knows my life-long struggle with getting a good night’s sleep. In honesty, my whole family struggles a bit with this, so we feel each other’s pain. Anyway, while this doesn’t actually induce sleep, it is such a calming, relaxing scent that you put on a few pulse points right before you go to bed. It helps me get into a much more zen-like state before snoozing. I've really been enjoying it! 

Black out curtains: this may be a no-brainer... But eliminating the light coming through the windows when you live in the city (or anywhere) is a major necessity for good sleep! 

Melatonin: When I’d tried this sporadically in the past, it didn’t offer much solace. However, when I made a routine of it and took it each night at the same time, I did find that it helped. Since this is a naturally occurring hormone in your body, it’s much better than some other sleep aids (which i’ll mention in a minute). There are so many reasons why your body may not be producing enough melatonin, one of them being stress. Being able to supplement melatonin, has been great for me. I’d recommend the lowest dose you can find if you’re just starting to try this—you can over-do it and wake up groggy. 

The Sense: this may seem like an extreme thing to try, but admittedly, it’s quite cool. This is a sleep tracker which hooks to your pillowcase and has a sensor which sits on your night stand or dresser; these transmit data about your sleep to an app on your phone. The data you can find is both about your sleep pattern and quality, but also tracks the air and light quality in your room. It’s actually very helpful to know that your room might feel fine to you right now, but it’s a bit too humid for quality sleep. Or, springing for those blackout curtains to completely block out the light from your windows will actually help you snooze better. On top of all of that, if you’re really bad at sleep—like me—you try new things to help (hence this entire post). With the sense, you’ll be able to see if those crazy techniques you tried actually work.

While this can be a big investment for the average person, it’s proven to be really handy for someone like me! 

What didn't work: 

Trying a firmer mattress: This is a total myth. Okay, so there is some truth to it, but it’s entirely up to you as a person and what type of mattress you’re most comfortable on. I have some back pain issues and frequently wake up very, very stiff. Trying a firmer mattress seemed to only exaggerate these pains, and actually made my sleep worse because of that. 

Sleep aid pills like Zquil: I only use these when i’m really dying for some sleep. Also, only when I don’t have anywhere to be the next morning. The problem with pills like these is they work too well. If you’re like me, and falling asleep isn’t really the problem, but rather staying asleep, these sleep aids may not be right for you. I was so, so groggy and out of it waking up after taking these. Also, i’ve noticed if you are keyed up from stress or excitement, they don’t work really at all, and then you’ve just popped pills for no reason.  

Earplugs: I am the world’s lightest sleeper. Hands down. Living in the city, this is quite the issue, don’t you think? I make great use of fans to provide some cover noise over anything that may be going on outside, or just the creaks of our old, old house. I thought earplugs would help. And this might be just something that affects me, but they really just hurt my ears, and I never really got used to sleeping with something stuffed inside them. These may work beautifully for others, though! 

What I would still like to try:

Ambient noise machine: I have friends who use and swear by these! 

A before sleep ritual: many people talk about these as well as their morning ritual. Giving your body cues that it’s time to power down and go to sleep can help regulate your circadian rhythm.  

Do you have any tips for getting better sleep?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: HOW TO DE-STRESS IN 10 MINUTES
item.content:encoded:
I might be one of the worst people in the world when it comes to handling stress. I’m completely awful at it. First off, i’m quite an expressive person; I totally wear my heart on my sleeve and my emotions quite clearly on my face. 

I think most of us need to get better at handling stress, however. I also think that there isn’t a perfect formula for it. However, if you’re like me and sometimes are purely stressed because there isn’t enough time to decompress, I think this quick routine will help you. 

Here’s how to destress your mind and body, in just 10 minutes. 

Meditate: 
Meditation is something I’ve flirted with as a practice before. Some of those closest to me swear by it—sitting each day, sometimes more than once. I’m not going to lie—it’s hard for me. Clearing my mind, sitting still, just breathing…doesn’t exactly describe something i’m known for. However, i’ve been trying to get better at it, and I’ve found it really does help. 

There are a few apps you can use for guided meditation (something I definitely recommend as a fellow beginner); the most popular ones I’ve heard talked about are HeadSpace & Calm. I’ve used HeadSpace, and liked it. There’s a pretty cool set up on there called the Take Ten Challenge, where you meditate for 10 minutes 10 days in a row. 

The one I’ve been using lately, though, is the Rituals app. Rituals makes a range of skincare and fragrance products, but they’ve also got a strong brand concentration on meditation. I first heard of this in a blog post on Vivanna Does Makeup. I really like the voice of the gal that does this one, so I tend to gravitate towards it. It’s a simple set up with different length options, but I prefer the 10 minute one, because it pairs with my next part of this calming routine. 

Put on a face mask: 
Does anyone else love doing face masks but not love having to sit and avoid doing things for 20-30 minutes because you have a bunch of goop on your face? That’s why i’m loving any mask that’s 10 minutes and under.

One of my favorites is the Origins Out Of Trouble 10 minute mask to rescue troubled skin. This does what it says on the package which is why I love it so much. It’s proven that what’s going on inside of you affects how you look on the outside—and stress all too often shows on my skin. I breakout, get dry patches when I don’t have dry skin, have excess redness, etc. You name the skin issue, i’ve probably seen stress manifest it on my face. This mask is very cooling on the skin, and really combats the pesky problems that come along with the not-so-relaxed moods. 

I find that when I’m choosing to meditate, putting this or another mask with the same time requirement helps me hit two birds with one stone. I’m relaxing my mind and body while helping my skin to reap the benefits. Triple win! 

Light a candle: 
think this one is possibly my favorite step. I love candles. Love them. I love great scents and I love picking them out and having them fill my home. However, how often do I stop to just appreciate the scent of some of my favorite candles? Not as often as I should. 

So, my final recommendation for mission destress is to light your favorite candle. And I mean your favorite. You know, the one you don’t burn as much because you’re afraid it will be gone too soon? Get it out, my friends. It’s worth it. 

One my my absolute favorite scents is apples. Any kind of apples. Apple scented things, and I mean the real apple scent, not the one that they give to candy, brings me so much joy. Lately, I’ve been burning this one from a local boutique called The Candle Lab, where you can mix and match and pour your own custom blended candle.  

Do you have a ritual for quick relaxation that you enjoy?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: 2016 MANTRA
item.content:encoded:
Before you start thinking "Man Susan, first your planner a little late and now the mantra while we're already one month in? sheesh."  Hear me out—

I've never been one to hold onto one word the entire year, and I've never set formal resolutions. So this year I was going about my normal business when I ended up listening to Estee Lalonde's interview on the Filler podcast. I was really enjoying it, as expected, and I really loved the way Estee, Matt, and Harry talked about mindfulness in relation to different things in life. At a certain point, they said "mindfulness is not bullshit". [sorry if the language offends you]

This really resonated with me. I've never been great at meditation, and I fall over a lot trying to do yoga. But I think that as these things become quite trendy and popular, it's even more important to remember that mindfulness is not limited to these things, nor are you an expert on it by attending a weekly session at a yoga studio. I think mindfulness can be applied to all things in life and practiced in many different ways. It's important to find what works for you.

I am going to try meditating more, likely by starting with Headspace's take ten challenge. I can document that here if anyone is interested in how it goes!

I'd also like to just practice being present more. Seeing small things in a space, appreciating their presence. Listening much more intently in conversations and being involved at every moment.
I'm also going to work on being more mindful of my body. I've been feeling great with my current workout regime, but I need to work on my eating habits. I think that by being more mindful of what i'm eating but, more importantly, how I feel after eating different things, will be a step in the right direction. I also have some work to do on appreciating my features instead of trying to change them. I love playing with makeup and the way it can completely transform or simply enhance. But I need to stop being hard on myself, as I think most of us are, and just love what I have.

So no, I didn't start out with this mantra on January first, but when it came to me via that podcast, I decided to make it a constant in my life this year. To really be mindful. It's not just a fad, it's not a joke, it's not something people just talk about to be in the conversation. It's a life practice, and something I'd like to be better at. 

Do you have a focus or mantra for 2016?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: CREATING MY OWN PLANNER
item.content:encoded:
In the beginning of December, the dreaded feeling of realizing your planner is coming to an end started to come over me. I was about to finish my fourth Moleskine Weekly Planner. A product which I do love very much and would recommend to anyone looking for a classy, simple way to organize their days. This time, though, I wanted to try something that offers a little more.
I've seen plenty of planners out there for different goals and focus areas. Most popular right now, I think, is the Erin Condren Life Planner. Now, I looked these up and down, and just wasn't sure I was into the myriad of colors going on. I prefer a minimal, clean look to planners.
There’s also the Get To Work Book, which is probably the closest thing to what I wanted, and as you can see was an inspiration for the design elements of mine. So, these two in mind, I set about my pro-con list to decide which one to purchase. I wanted to do some goal tracking on a monthly basis, and I wanted to include fun things as well.
When it came down to it, I couldn’t pull the trigger on either of them. I just didn’t feel 100% in on them. And, if you’re type A like me, you know what i’m talking about. A planner is something you’ll carry around every day for an entire year. Not to mention, I tend to hang on to them for a while after they’re full, like documentation of what I did the year before. I find them pretty cool to look back on occasionally.

Now, there’s nothing really wrong with any of the planners I mentioned above, it’s just that they were either lacking something I wanted, or had too many extras that I wouldn’t get use out of.
This lead me to try my hand at creating my own planning system. So, I started mocking up what I thought I wanted my days to look like in a planner. I took inspiration from many planners I’d surveyed in my search, and landed on a very simple set up of a schedule, to-do list, and a section for notes. I later ended up adding a section to take note of what was for dinner each day, as a goal I have for this year is to get more adventurous in the kitchen.

I printed out a few of these days to test them out in the first work week of the year, and I really liked them. I started thinking that I actually might just go for it and make my own—get it professionally printed and bound and everything. From there, a friend of mine sent me a link to this post, where the author talks about how he used a site called blurb.com to make his own planner and get it printed for super cheap. This was the golden ticket! That same friend also happens to be a designer (check out her Esty shop!), and she offered to help me with the design of my planner. We got it set up into this order:
Photo pages
Monthly Calendars + Plans
Weekly Overviews
Daily Pages
Monthly Reflections

We messed around with the look of it and how everything flowed, but I was pretty positive about what I wanted so it didn't take long. It cost about $26 using Blurb to get it color printed and hard bound. Score.
And can I say—I’m obsessed with how it turned out!
The paper quality is really top notch; there is absolutely zero bleed through from my trusty Pilot Precise V5's and really no ghosting either. 

I only ordered the beginning of the year through the end of June, so if I want any changes I can make those for the second half of the year. I will likely have an update style post coming in a few months to let you know how i'm liking it and what I would change! 

What planning system do you swear by?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: 3 TIPS FOR SAVING MONEY AS A YOUNG PRO
item.content:encoded:
Can I even call myself a "young pro"? That sounds so official. When did that happen?

I digress. 

When it comes to saving money, there's a million ways to do it right, and a million ways to do it wrong. Everyone has different opinions, and I really don't believe you have to be a professional or consult a professional to save efficiently in the way you need to. Whether i'm saving for a big, exciting purchase, a splurge item i've had my eye on, or just the monthly expenses we all love to hate-I have a few ways that I like to do things when it comes to saving. 

Disclaimer: I'm not an accountant or finance consultant, nor do I claim some sort of authority on this subject. Also, I really don't think i'm by any means the best at saving, but i've gotten better over the years, and for now these tips really work for me. 

1. Separate your checking and savings accounts

Seems like a no brainer, right? Well, not exactly. For years, I used a bank that had a really awesome set up. I had a long term savings account, a short term, and a "spend" account that was my checking account. This seems amazing, money was very easy to move between accounts, and if I went over what was in the checking it would pull from the short term savings, then the long term. No over-drafting? Perfecto. Not so much. The money was so easily transferred out of savings, and I became really lax at actively saving more and more each month. I don't know about you, but for me it's kind of a mind game. I can't see all of my money, because then I'm comforted that splurge purchases are okay and I make them more often. I need to trick myself into thinking my checking account is all I have and I am much more frugal. 
So, last year, I switched to a different bank (the big switch was for different reasons) and to a different set up. Now, I have a much more traditional thing going. Separate accounts for saving and checking, both of which I can still access easily but they aren't connected directly, hey—a little separation is healthy for my moolah. 

2. Get real about your budget

Budgets aren't just for squares, you can be fun and have one, too! While I don't keep a spreadsheet or anything, it's good to know just how much true disposable income you have. There are some really cool services that help with budgets, like Mint, where you can set spending limits for different categories. I've used this before and think it's good, but I wasn't a fan of having yet another system, so I fell out of using it. 
An easy way to get a birds eye view of your budget is to start with how much money you bring in on any given month. My job pays me by salary, so i'm lucky enough to have a steady amount. If you're a freelancer or working hourly, I'd suggest taking the total amount earned each month for about three or four months where you had a normal workload for you and averaging it out.
From there, start subtracting!
Take your living expenses out, your car, insurance, student loans, groceries, cell phone plan, etc. Don't forget to also subtract what you're putting aside for savings! (some may also want to include an IRA or investment fund, if you've chosen to go that route.) I also subtract the $200.00 I know I will spend each month on personal training. (yes, quite the expense, but so worth it for me.)
What you're left with is what you can afford to spend on things like eating out, drinks, clothes, makeup, etc. 
If we're being completely honest, I tend to walk around everyday telling myself i'm broke. Even if i'm not, it's just the best way for me to make myself step back and really think about purchases and how much I need the thing I'm lusting after. 

3. You need to be doing short and long term saving

Was anyone else ever told growing up that you should put 25% of everything you make into a savings account? Wowza. Mom and Dad didn't know that I'd grow up to love shoes so much, I guess. But really, if you're doing that (major kudos to you, my friend) and it's supposed to be your cushion so you can retire before you're 90—what happens when you want to travel? Or splurge on those Jimmy Choos? OR want to explore the wonderful experience of getting a dog? 
You need to be able to save short term in tandem with saving for the long term—while still maintaining your monthly expenses. 
I have a suggestion for how to help with this: 
If you're like me, and need saving to be mindless (aka you've set up auto transfers into your savings account so you can't skip these, ever), you should definitely check out a service called Digit. It's a startup that's focused on helping people save their money in a smart, efficient way. When you first sign up and sync your bank account, it analyzes your spending habits. Their system will determine your lowest threshold for cash in the account you link to it. From there, it will take small amounts daily and transfer the money into an FDIC insured savings account Digit keeps for you. Since it knows your threshold—it will never take you below that point. (preeeetty cool, eh?) Anywho, for this account, you don't earn interest. Which can seem like a ding for the service, but really, it's just as if you were saving money in a piggy bank or a coffee can, so that's never bothered me. Another really awesome part of Digit is how it bases all communication with it's users in SMS text messages. They send you texts to update you on how much you've got in the account, and how much they saved you each week. 
I can honestly say I rarely notice the amounts they take out until I get that end-of-week message stating how much they saved for me. If you want to withdrawal the money, you text them and say so, and they transfer it back into your personal account within one business day. You can also save more than what they're taking out, if you want—just text them and let them know! 
Frankly, it's one of the best things i've ever done. It's how i'm handling all of my short term saving for any trips or bigger purchases. 

Again, i'm no professional. I don't have a degree in finance, and i'm not the worlds best money-saver or frugal shopper. I will skip coupons if it's more convenient. (oops, did I just say that?.. sorry.) But, I proudly (and hopefully not arrogantly) carry the experience of having put myself through a bachelor's degree at a state university, and it wasn't cheap. Somehow (and I say somehow because most day's i'm still not quite sure how I pulled it off), I paid tuition, rent, phone, car—the works—all while working as a server at a restaurant and still managing some semblance of a social life. Those four years taught me that taking care of myself financially is not only essential, but something i'm completely capable of. 

I hope you're finding your way to figuring out finances, no matter what stage of life you're in! 

Do you have any tips on saving money while still enjoying this wonderfully unknown stage we call our twenties? 

 

I was not asked to write this post by anyone or any company/service mentioned. These are 100% my thoughts and opinions.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WELCOME
item.content:encoded:
Hello!

For lack of a better intro, let's get right into this: I’ve been writing aimlessly for years now and I've had this site set up for months without doing much on it. But, I think it’s time I define all of this a bit more. At first, I wanted to play around with SquareSpace and possibly find a spot on the interwebs to house my portfolio. Also, since my job involves working with bloggers using different platforms and product guys who build things to help them, I thought I should familiarize myself with the good ol’ square as it's growing in popularity and still quite unknown (when compared to something like WordPress). 

As I said, for years i’ve collected my thoughts in writing. It’s always been a natural extension of me. It’s the way I worked through issues, kept track of memories, and celebrated wins both big and small. Lately, I find myself scribbling notes and thoughts more than ever, about all sorts of things. Some are quite meaningful to me and deeply opinionated. Others, are light hearted and sometimes about things you may think are silly (like makeup and beauty products). But nonetheless, I really enjoy writing about all of it. 

When I started playing with the CMS for work reasons, I used my own writings as filler for posts and pages. It sure did look like I was blogging. I wasn’t promoting it anywhere. I wasn’t looking for an audience. I did like seeing my words in a more real home-and what goes better with words than photos?

I sure do love (amateurishly) taking photos. 

So, here we are. Welcome! 

Here's more specific details about howThe Desk of Susan came to be:

The name for this site was a tough thing. It really was a hurdle holding me back. I can’t say I came up with it. (s/o to my boyfriend) But I did however, completely fall in love with it when I realized what it meant to me. My grandfather, the most influential man in my life, was so particular about his words. He had a singular type of pen that he would use, and a slew of notepads that were personalized with “From the desk of Ronald Roat.” As a child, I thought it was cheesy. As I considered this name for my blog, I realized that it was brilliant. That’s how he owned his words, that’s how everyone knew they were his. So, I use this to tell you that these words are mine, and i’m taking ownership of what i’m now sharing with the world. 

Before I thought I’d ever go public with this, I asked that same boyfriend of mine (a talented designer) if he’d mind making me a logo—just for fun. For sh*ts & gigs, you know? He did so (beautifully, I might add), I added it here, and realized I was kind of in love with the idea of blogging. (Queue sparkly music and fairy dust.)

So what’s been holding me back?
What holds everyone back: fear, anxiety, self consciousness, being another voice in a sea of many.

I’d like to overcome those. I’d like to use this site as my outlet for all the thoughts and opinions that may or may not fit into my professional world, but are still encompassed in who I am. I’d like this site to be mine. And I’d like to share it with you. 

 Here's why I hope you'll come back:

On this site you'll find my many musings about what's going on in my life. This could include: items & products i'm loving, projects i've been working on, my not-so-seasoned advice on various subjects, my travels, and much more. I hope to grow and learn in writing and photography through The Desk of Susan. Most importantly: I hope this chance i'm taking now, sharing this passion project of mine, will encourage me to take more chances in the future.

Now, for the corny bit:
Here’s to new adventures. Here’s to embracing fear and judgement. Here’s to the unknown. 


Thanks to all who join me along the way!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Your grandfather would be awestruck with you. I believe he would think it a very high honor to be a part of your inspiration! Let your words fly!

item.title: PHOTO DIARY: 25TH BIRTHDAY
item.content:encoded:
As promised, a photo diary from my birthday celebrations! 

This is a real look into how I celebrated my birthday this year. Nothing is staged, although I did force my friends to pose for a few pictures for me :). My original plan was to have a more artsy-style photo diary, but then I realized to get those types of shots, the photographer would have to be an observer, rather than a participant. And I wanted everyone in attendance to be participating! So, we grabbed an Instax camera and captured some shots, which I'm sharing with you edit-free. Here's a look into real life for me: we invited some of my great friends over to our home, had some (a lot) of drinks, and it was a blast. Yes, I drink good beer and cheap beer. Yes, we played a drinking game. Yes, you'll see lots of bug spray because mosquitos eat the sh*t out of me. Yes, we are goofballs. And yes, it was a birthday for the books. Thanks to everyone who celebrated and sent well wishes!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: PHOTO DIARY: MUST VISIT SPOTS IN INDIANAPOLIS
item.content:encoded:
I've made many trips to Indy, but never really spent time just walking the city. When Nick and I went out for a concert recently, we spent an entire day exploring, mostly in the neighborhood called Broad Ripple. I've snapped some pics of my favorite spots we visited! 

We had breakfast at Milktooth, which is in a neighborhood called Fletcher Place. It's a really cool diner with a very tasty menu! I had the strawberry rhubarb pancake and nick had the steak and eggs. We sat at the bar right in front of the cooks—we both love to see how kitchens operate and watch people who are craftsmen when it comes to cooking! The food was divine. They also have a pretty enticing pastry selection which I managed to (just barely) steer clear of. Tons of character here and great food, what more could you ask for?

Next we hit up one of the coolest stores I've ever been in. I'm serious. If you're in Indianapolis, like reading and beautiful photos, you need to go to PRINTtEXT. It's a periodicals shop where you'll find the most intriguing and enticing magazines. We're not talking what you pick up while waiting in the checkout line at the grocery store—these are high production quality, beautifully crafted magazines that cover a myriad of topics. They are usually on the pricey side, but the value is high to match the cost. You'll find in depth interviews and unique photos taken by renowned photographers covering any niche you can think of. I am really drawn to travel magazines, so I picked up a copy of the eleventh issue of  Boat magazine, which is entirely about Havana, Cuba. 

While exploring the rest of Broad Ripple, we stopped into brics for some delicious ice cream, caught this gorgeous wall of ivy at Petite Chou out of the corner of our eyes, and Nick had to peel me away from Alley Girls, a fun used furniture and decor shop which had tons of character pieces. We stopped into Public Greens for some lunch,  which is unique in that they grow most of their ingredients right outside of the restaurant! I had a Thai Barely salad which was the perfect light lunch for a day of exploring.

All of these spots are must-visits the next time you're in Indianapolis!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: PHOTO DIARY: FLOWER SHOW
item.content:encoded:
This past weekend was the Cincinnati Flower Show here in town, so Nick and I went to have a look and get some great photos of one of my favorite things about this earth: flowers! 

If you’ve never heard of it before, the Cincinnati Flower Show is put on by the Cincinnati Horticultural Society each year and this year they partnered with the Cincinnati USA Sister City Association to put on a spectacular show of exhibits and vendors! People come in from all over the world to display their work and sell their plants and flowers. You can find vendors selling plants, unique flowers, and even food + drink. 

There were also exhibits of beautiful flower arrangements and gardening. We really loved our time there! 

Here are my pictures from the day:  

Are there any events like this near you?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: PHOTO DIARY: NASHVILLE
item.content:encoded:
This past weekend was Nick + I's anniversary, and he surprised me with a weekend trip to Nashville! It's a city I've been to a few times when I was younger, but this time we explored the parts of the city which are far from the famous honky-tonks on Broadway. 

We stayed at the Aloft hotel; the place had a very cool vibe with live music in the bar. (not uncommon for this town) When walking around we saw a lot of both Vanderbilt and Belmont's campuses, which are of course beautiful! Near Vanderbilt in Hilsboro Village, we gawked over the line at Pancake Pantry, ended up getting an awesome breakfast at Fido instead, and had a quick coffee/tea break at Revelator (highly recommend this place!). 

There's another neighborhood not far from Hilsboro called 12 South that's full of beautiful shops, taprooms, and eateries. There's such a great vibe to this neighborhood, and the weather was perfect so everyone was out and about. 

An interesting thing about this area is that many of the shops and restaurants seem to be in old auto service stations, which gives a really open vibe with a feeling of history, like the place has been lived in and seen some things. We loved it. A few notable shops are Imogene + Willie, S'more Love Bakery, and Amelia's Flower Truck. 

Check out my photos from the trip below:
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: Tea Time: Inner Peace
item.content:encoded:
What's "tea time" you ask? Well, as I'm not a coffee drinker (only when maximum caffeine is needed), I didn't want to call this more reflection-style series "coffee talk". On top of not really being a coffee drinker—I'm a massive tea drinker. Peppermint tea is my spirit animal. I also love a good London Fog in the cooler months. The gist is, I'm starting a series where once a week, I'm going to talk about something that's on my mind. It might be deep, it might be light hearted. It might be impactful, or it might just be me rambling on about something that's been rattling around in my brain. I hope you like it, and if you have any thoughts on any Tea Time posts, I'd love to chat in the comments! Grab yourself a cup of tea (or coffee), and let's chat: 

Inner peace. 
That sounds kind of heavy, right? Inner peace.
I’ll start by saying I have no expertise on this subject. I’m not a therapist nor did I study psychology, but I’m someone who struggles with finding her inner peace.
My struggle comes from wanting to do everything, and all at once. I’m never sure which path is the right to take, which project to throw myself into, and what decisions will lead me to the life I’m trying to design for myself. I frequently find myself stressing about this. Let me tell you, it can be pretty debilitating, and you can quickly fall into a hole of self doubt. Today’s tea time isn’t about telling you how to figure it all out, because lord knows I have next to nothing figured out. It’s about letting you know that you’re not alone if you’re in the same boat. I’ve had friends tell me “look at you, working hard and keeping up with a passionate side project, you’re doing the dang thing!” And while I am eternally grateful for these kind words and flattered that some may think that—in my head it’s a different story.
I feel as if i’m in a bit of a holding pattern. I have all of this pent up ambition (and flat out angst) that I want to funnel into what matters to me, but I’m not sure how just yet. I’m not speaking about personal details (I’m beyond lucky to have my family, friends, and relationship), but more what some might call my “career”, and what I’d just call my life. This blog was started so that I could write, and turned in to be my outlet for teaching myself photography at the same time.
The reason I tie this to the thought of inner peace comes in with figuring out how to get where I want to go. If I’m not able to reach a balance within myself, I’ll never stay on the necessary path, or make the right changes to that path. There’s no right way. That can be the hardest part sometimes. Being at peace with yourself allows you to properly direct your energy and creativity to where it’s most productive for you.

I’m trying something out these days: when I feel overwhelmed and like I don’t have the agency to change things, I’m writing down those feelings. Immediately followed by these two things: something I’m grateful for, and a small step I could take to get on track. This could seem silly, but even the act of putting pen to paper clears my mind. Even if I write nothing sensical at all, I feel better. Channeling my emotions into remembering what I’m grateful for helps to keep be grounded, and noting what I can do to change it shows me I’m not helpless, but being consumed by those feelings is.

I think we’re all trying to find our inner peace. Even those who wouldn’t change a thing in life (do those people even exist?), are doing things to maintain a peaceful balance within themselves.

Do you have any tips or exercises for finding inner peace?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: LETTER TO AUGUST
item.content:encoded:
Dear August, 

Oh, my my. Well August, it’s time to say goodbye. You were hot and semi-miserable. However, Fitzgerald came home, and that has been a blessing. He’s a handful and a ball of love. With you August, my patience and stress has been pushed to it’s limits. I love my pup immensely, but it was definitely a big adjustment. Now, August, as you ride off into the distance, my little family has found a balance that works for us. We’re getting well into the groove of having a four-legged dog-child, and things are looking up. He’s getting so big! I cannot wait to watch him continue to grow and learn. I must say, August, I’m ready for your dear friend September. I’m so ready for the cooler temperatures. The sweaters, the days in the park, and long walks through our city. While like July, you didn’t see the changes I was thinking you may, I’m content with that. It’s all a journey, and August you were a great step along the way. 

—Susan
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: 5 PIECES ESSENTIAL TO YOUR SPRING WARDROBE TRANSITION
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="700.0"] Image via [/caption]

Leather jacket- as I like to say, adding a leather jacket to any outfit instantly doubles your badass points. It’s the perfect “i’m professional, but not too professional” touch. You’ll look grown up but still young and carefree. Shop my favorite options here (steal), here (invest), and here (splurge).

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="599.0"] Image via [/caption]

Denim jacket- a recent “shop my closet” discovery has been my denim jacket. When I first purchased this a few years ago, I struggled to find my jam with it, yet I couldn’t let it go. I’m very glad I kept it because this spring I have so many outfits planned for it! I like the way it looks over just about any kind of top, or tied around the waist over a relaxed fit t-shirt. Get a great denim jacket for yourself here or here.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="640.0"] Image via [/caption]

Distressed jean- this style goes in and out, but for me it’s pretty much always in. I’m a huge self proclaimed spokesperson for the Topshop Jamie Jeans, specifically the ones with distressed details. I think it adds a touch of personality to an otherwise plain bottom half. Get these jeans here or here.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="710.0"] Image via [/caption]

Neutral sneakers- sneakers are the way, my friends. It’s something the Europeans have had down pat for years, but it’s finally starting to surface in the US. I have to admit, sneakers are my favorite footwear. There, I said it, it’s out there. I restrain myself when shopping so that I don’t end up with too many, but they just make your outfit look so effortless. If you are looking for a one pair fits all deal, I’d suggest some with a neutral palette like these or these.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="700.0"] Image via [/caption]

V-neck t-shirts: Does this one even need an explanation? Not only are v-necks pretty much universally flattering, they go with everything. Pair them with anything listed above for an effortlessly chic outfit this spring! These are my favorite, but I also love these. 

What are your go-to items for spring?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: MY TRAVEL WISHLIST
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="650.0"] Image via LadySlider [/caption]

Morocco— I’ve wanted to go to africa for a long time now, and morocco always caught my eye. The colorful culture, great food, and warm temps seem like my kinda place. With all of the markets to explore and a wildly different cultural experience than anywhere I've been, it's high on my list! 

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="830.0"] Image via The Fresh Exchange [/caption]

Portugal— this is a tiny bit of a cheat, because Nick and I are planning to go there this year. We’re looking to go to Lisbon for around 7-9 days, and I couldn’t be more excited! The beautiful colors and breathtaking architecture are definitely a draw. I’ve also never been to a country that speaks portugese…nor do I know a single word… so that should be fun! I’m excited to learn some conversational phrases and explore the beautiful, water-side town.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1500.0"] Image via Tuula [/caption]

Italy— is there anyone out there who doesn’t want to visit Italy? I mean, hello, PASTA. Right? Right. And besides the pasta, it’s just seemingly an all around beautiful place. I’d definitely like to spend time in all the usual suspects of Italy.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1440.0"] Image via Conde Nast Traveller [/caption]

Ireland—This is partly influenced by the fact that i’m part Irish, and partly by my love of cooler, coastal places that aren’t necessarily a spring break destination. My brother recently spent three weeks in the UK and had wonderful things to say about Ireland, which only feeds my fire more.
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com
