item.title: PHOTO DIARY: US ROAD TRIP
item.content:encoded:
A little over a year ago, myself along with the two other members of my team at work got to go on one crazy, exhausting, exhilarating, wonderful road trip across the US.

Without getting into too much detail, we directly build and nurture relationships with content creators who use our online tools. The goal of this trip was to meet these content creators, IRL, and spend some time getting to know them. We took a poll and found the cities which were the most populated by our Ahalogy family and took off!

With meet-ups each night in a different city, we hit 9 cities in 10 days, starting in NYC and ending in San Fransisco.
Along the way we stopped in: NYC, Philly, D.C., Atlanta, Chicago, Kansas City, Denver, Salt Lake City, and San Fransisco.

Yes, that means we spent roughly 12 hours each day in the car, high-tailing it to the next city. While it was absolutely insane and there were days I thought I’d rather just hop a plane home out of pure exhaustion, it was one of the best things I’ve ever done. I saw so much of this amazing country that I wouldn’t have seen otherwise, and I met people face to face who I’d previously only been able to talk to through a computer screen.

I took plenty of pictures to document the journey, and I’d like to share a few with you: 

 

Have you gone on any trips you really loved? Share your stories!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WORKFLOW #2: SOUNDS OF PRODUCTIVITY
item.content:encoded:
Follow my blog with Bloglovin

Due to the nature of my job, and just a general interest in the topic, I do a lot of reading in my free time around productivity and motivation. When you're pulling long, intense hours in front of a screen where every minute in your work day is a whirlwind, it's nice to know there are ways to improve the work you're doing. I've noticed that many, many other folks who work in similar situations can say the same. I'm explaining this because it leads me to try out a ton different types of sounds to listen to while working. Ambient sounds, upbeat music, chill music, instrumentals.
The other thing about my work life—we have an open office space. We're one big family in one big room, working on different tasks that will drive us toward our common goals. Sounds peachy-keen, right? It can be very cool. And most of the time, it is. However, there are times when the hustle and bustle can be too much, and it's hard to focus on the task or project at hand. 
When that happens, I retreat into my headphones, turn on a great playlist, ambient noises that help me relax and focus, or a combination of both. 

I also work from home a day or two each week, but the silence can also turn out to be a deterrent from productivity as well! 

Since ambient sound is probably more abstract to some, i'll start there. I've tried out a number of different apps that do this, and have many different sounds to choose from. The one i've become loyal to is called Noiz.io. This is an app for Macs, and it's downright fabulous. With sounds like beach waves, campfire, summer night, Paris cafe, etc. i'm sure you'd be in agreement that there's something for everyone. Another great thing about this app—you can layer the sounds on top of each other, and adjust the volume for each so you can make one more prominent than others. Right now, i've been rocking the oh-so-wonderful combo of beach waves and sunny day. I may or may not be chalking it up to "preparing" myself for my upcoming trip. With this combo, the waves slowly roll in all day, with birds chirping in the background. I also love a good dose of Paris Cafe with, well, any other choices. Who doesn't want to feel like they're in Paris?

My other major source of sound at work (and during all other times of life) are Spotify playlists. Spotify is the bomb. It's just that simple. While you don't have to pay for the premium version, I do highly suggest it, as it makes life so much easier. My favorite part of Spotify premium is the ability to save offline music. This means you can listen to those songs and lists without wifi or using data. It's basically how I survive going for runs, since I don't like to use my data service. (anyone else feel like they go through that standard 2 gigs super quick?) 
Here's some of my go-to playlists: 

Current : this is a personal list, curated by yours truly. This list basically sums up my mood at any given moment. I am constantly adding—and removing—songs from here based on what i'm jamming to. I'll also throw new/popular songs on there to make sure I give them a listen. 

Feelin' Good : this list is curated by Spotify, old tunes that do just as it says—make you feel good. I'm a sucker for this type of music. Who doesn't like to feel good? 

Peaceful piano : this one is also curated by Spotify, and consists of Piano instrumentals. If you're not a fan of that type of music, you might want to skip this one (and maybe the next as well). I find sometimes when I need to seriously focus, music with lyrics distracts me. The piano puts me at east and lets me get down to business. This list has some very popular tunes that everyone is pretty much guaranteed to know, so that's a plus! 

Coffee table jazz : another (you guessed it) curated by Spotify. They are seriously so good at creating lists. Which I guess is a given being in that biz? Probably. Anywho, if you're not a fan of jazz, I seriously don't know how to help you. Kidding. I've always been a lover of this music, and it just instantly lifts my spirits. Again with no lyrics, cause that's just how I like it sometimes. 

What sounds and music to you listen to at work?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: WORKFLOW #1: WORKING REMOTELY
item.content:encoded:
One of the cool parts of my job is that we can really work from wherever we want. Home, a coffee shop, a different office, a different city. I personally think this essential for promoting a healthy company full of happy employees. It allows us to decide where we will be most productive while working, and change that up if we don't have a great vibe in a space. 
For months, i've chosen to work out of the office at least once a week. Although recently with the addition of my puppy, Fitz, i’ve been doing this much more so I can be closer to the apartment when he needs to be taken outside!
Usually, these days are broken up into two 4-hour working blocks. Sounds normal, right? I find when i’m in the office I work a bit less consistently. I have lunch at different times, conversations with co-workers go down, I’m much less consistent about the solid blocks of work vs the lunch/walk breaks, etc. Not to say this is a bad thing, because it’s still the same amount of time working each day, it’s just broken up differently. 
With these two working blocks of time, there’s a couple different ways or scenes I like to put myself in for good focus: 

1. Working in my apartment
I’m lucky enough to have a big ol’ second monitor at home, and honestly it’s way nicer than the one I have on my desk at work. (although the one at the office doesn’t deter me from any good work) I also am in a space where I am comfortable and happy, which helps me when i’m working on intense projects or something that’s tedious. Sometimes, I even work from time to time on my couch (queue all the gawks from ergonomic experts). While I am the first to admit that working on the couch isn’t the best for my focus, or comfort when you have chronic back pain, it’s nice when I’m working through some “busy work”. What’s busy work? Cleaning up spreadsheets, folders of documents, converting lead information in our CRM, etc. Things that need to get done, but don’t actually require that 100% focus factor. For all other work I stick to the dining table or my desk. 

2. Working at local coffee shops and cafe’s
When i’m either finding it hard to focus at home (happens when you have a pup that may be whining in his crate, or a stack of dishes in the sink you’d prefer were clean and put away…..signs of adulthood?), I hit up  a local coffee shop or cafe. Currently, we live within walking distance of one of my favorite neighborhoods in Cincinnati called Over The Rhine. There’s a host of little places with great coffee, tea, food, and wifi. I find when I need to vibe of people being around with ambient noise, these establishments are perfect. (1215 Coffee lab & Wine bar shown above)


Do you work in an office or remote? Where are your favorite places to work?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: PLANNING CHECK IN: WHAT SYSTEM WORKS?
item.content:encoded:
If you read my post from the beginning of the year, I designed my own planner and had it printed. While I did love it, it was pretty bulky, and because of that the pages would never lay flat. Now we’ve come to the point where I must tell you: i’m a notebook snob. I am super particular. Down to the point where I like a certain Moleskine in a certain size in a certain color. I also tend to like completely blank pages, although that could be changing based on something I’ll mention in a bit. 

When I realized the planner wasn’t actually going to work for me, I was pretty down. I am very pleased with how it turned out, it just ended up not working the way that I thought it would. 

I quickly switched to just writing in my trusty Moleskine and went back to just jotting down to-do lists each day. I was pretty bummed about the planner situation, so I did some more research on planner and organization tips. I still was unable to find a pre-made planner I thought I would really like, but I did stumble on the world of bullet journaling. And when I say world, I mean it. There’s a huge community of people who are taking the original bullet journal system, putting their own twist on it, and creating content to share their systems. The most notable to me was Boho Berry. She’s my inspiration as well as the inspiration or many others I’m sure! 

Now, I am not at her level. I only have one color pen, my trusty Pilot V5 in black. But, I am enjoying playing with basic “spreads”. Right now I just do my own version of a weekly spread where I have a list of my events/appointments for the week, a to-do list, my meals for the week, and any overarching goals or inspiration I might have for that week. 

From there, I’m doing a much more relaxed set up for my daily lists, sticking pretty much to the original bullet journal system of bullets, X’s, open circles, and arrows. 

  • Bullets: tasks to be completed
  • Crossed out with an X: indicates a completed task
  • Open circles: and event, such as a meeting. 
  • Arrows: a task that has been migrated to the next day.

I am finding I really enjoy not having a set space to work with for any given day. Some days I take extra notes in my book, and some days I do not. Sometimes I have an unusually fast growing task list. So, not closing out the day before the day is over, and just starting the next day wherever the last happened to leave off, works well for this! Strangely, that may be my favorite part about organizing myself with this system. 

The only change I am looking into is getting a moleskine with dotted or grid pages, because it seems to be much neater and easier to stay neat. Normally, I stick to blank pages. I’ll admit, I’m so notebook-snobby that I like different page treatments for different situations. For work + blog organization, I really prefer unruled pages. There’s something about a crisp, clean, blank page that I’ve always found satisfying. But, because I’m also a cute notebook hoarder, I have found use for ruled pages in other areas of note-taking life. In this case, I’m willing to branch out and try the dots/grid. I am considering a habits tracker, like this one, where I know those page treatments will really come in handy. 

So there you have it, an update on my journalling and task organization! Somewhat of a grey cloud to start with that has a shiny silver lining. A takeaway I hope you have from this is that trying things out and testing your ideas is always something you should do. It might not work out, or it could be perfect. I really did put work into creating the planner I had made, but I’m willing to admit I didn’t end up creating my perfect system! I only know that because I gave it a shot. 

For more bullet journaling ideas, tips, and tricks, check out Boho Berry whom I mentioned above. She really is a very creative person and her discipline is endearing. Or, just try searching the #bulletjournal tag on Instagram, you’ll find tons of inspiration there!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: GETTING OUR PUPPY VOL 3
item.content:encoded:
He's home! He's a sweet, energetic, loving ball of fur. 
While I love him very much and even at this point wouldn’t ever want to not have him, he’s a lot of work. A lot. 
He does well in his crate, although he doesn’t quite see it as his safe place like we want him to feel in the future. He’s not house broken, so we’re working on that the best we can. Which involves taking him out every 4 hours at least. If he’s just eaten or had water, he goes out more frequently. It’s a big schedule change for us, to make sure we’re home to do these things as needed. 
In addition, we’re training him till he’s ready to go to a puppy class. He's so smart and really seems to enjoy going through commands with us! He has an evaluation in the coming days with a trainer so we can get him into a class. 

The first few weeks are definitely about getting to know each other, and testing each other. He’s testing us, and we are trying to test him as well. This process is not without it’s stress and the occasional stretch of sanity, but I know that it will be more than worth it. 

The thing about getting a puppy is it’s an investment. You choose to get a puppy instead of a grown dog so you can raise it yourself and train it or have it trained the way you’d like. All of the hard work now will pay off ten fold when Fitz is a well behaved dog who still loves to have fun with us. (well, that’s the plan :) ) 

He's very lovable and so chill. Sure, he has his bursts of energy and speeds around the house, but he's overall very calm for a puppy. We are loving having him around, and now that we are falling into a better rhythm with caring for him the "new parent" stress is lightening up. 

Here's a shot of our stud I snapped over the weekend:  

For more photos of him you can follow me or him on Instagram! 
@susansogood
@captainfitz_
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: A WINNING CONCEALER DUO
item.content:encoded:
As i'm sure most gals who are into beauty can say, finding that perfect concealer is almost the number one priority as far as bases go. If you're at all like me, blemish & redness prone, highly sensitive, with some old hyper-pigmentation and scarring hanging around—the right concealer is the difference between a flawless look and, well, a not-so-flawless look. I love Queen B as much as the next person (okay, maybe even a little more), but I usually did not wake up like this. (although I do dream of those days when I may not have to wear foundation)

I've tested a lot of different brands, formulas, and colors for concealer. I enjoy a highlighting formula for my under eyes (two hands in the hair for all my dark-circle sufferers), and a pretty creamy, full coverage formula for blemishes or scars.

There a few in both category which I like to keep on the bench, just in case I feel like I need them, but there are two star players which are very, very well loved.

The under eye concealer that takes the gold for me is the Rimmel London Match Perfection Skin Tone Adapting Concealer. This baby is my dream come true. I've used it everyday since I got it, without fail. It's lightweight, but still covers the deep blue circles I get, and blends like a dream leaving the skin looking natural. It's also great to take this one onto the eyelids as a bit of a primer to cancel and veins or discoloration, as well as down the nose & between the brows for a little extra brightness.

I don't think it will be any sort of surprise to hear that the NARS Radiant Creamy Concealer is a true love of mine when it comes to full coverage base products. It's so creamy, so pigmented, and lasts all day. It does take a bit of work with the blending, but it's perfectly doable with fingers, a sponge, or a brush. I prefer either a buffing or a stippling brush for this guy, dabbing just a bit over what i'd like to cover with the doe-foot applicator, then using a circular stippling/patting motion to blend it in, and building up the coverage when needed. Remember to start small with this one, since it's such full coverage—a little goes a long way!

While I highly recommend both of these products, there are a few others that deserve and honorable mention which you might find in my arsenal:
Maybeline Dream Lumi Touch 
Benefit boi-ing Concealer
Maybeline Instant Age Rewind Eraser
Maybeline Fit Me Concealer
Estee Lauder Double Wear Stay In Place High Cover Concealer (annddd breathe)
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: A FACE FOR MONDAYS
item.content:encoded:
It's a quick one today- wanted to share my really simple makeup routine that's ending up being my beginning of the week, back to work go-to look. 

I start with the base of all bases (that never seems to get enough love in the beauty world), Clinique's Even Better foundation. It's been around for years, and I've been using it this whole time. Sometimes it gets buried in the bottom of the drawer, but when I want a flawless, skin-like, demi-matte finish, I always come back to this one.  

From there I'll sweep a little Benefit Hoola basically all over my face to warm it up, followed by tapping some Becca Shimmering Skin Perfecter in the shade Moonstone over my cheek bones. 

With the eyes I've been grabbing the Bobbi Brown Long Wear Cream Shadow Stick in the shade Sunlight Gold, going all over the lid and heavy on the inner corners to highlight. Then it's a few coats of Maybeline The Rocket mascara to really give the lashes an oomph. 

I finish off the look with one of my favorite pinky nude shades, the revlon lip butter in berry smoothie, and I'm out the door!  

What's your go-to simple look for a Monday?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: HOW TO: GET THAT GLOW FROM WITHIN COMPLEXION
item.content:encoded:
Everyone knows that contouring and highlighting have been all the rage as of late. While I like a lil’ sculpt for a night out, i’m definitely not one to do this on a daily basis. I do, however, firmly stand behind a nice glowy complexion to make a gal look healthy. I have very oily skin. Let me repeat: very oily. I’ve also got some dehydrated patches, it’s very sensitive, and breakout-prone. Joy! While I tend to lean more towards fuller coverage matte finish foundations, there are a few lighter & dewier ones I enjoy slapping on from time to time as well. No matter the coverage and finish, I always use this one tactic when i’m looking for a lit from within—not disco ball—glow.

The (not-so) secret?: Applying both highlighter and blush underneath your foundation.

Won’t the foundation just cover it up, you ask? That depends on the products and colors you use.

For the full coverage & matte foundations:

Since this foundation’s job is to combat shine and discoloration, I go a little bit clowny, but only for a moment. For this, I like using the NYX Born To Glow liquid illuminator in the shade Sunbeam. This is a very cool toned, pale pink highlight with serious sheen and shimmer. There’s also a hint of glitter in it (which is why I don’t use it on top of a base). For blush, I go for the NXY Rouge Cream Blush in the shade Glow. It’s quite the bright pink, and does look scary at first, there’s no denying. I apply this either with a small stippling brush or just my fingertips, and blend it out. Here’s where you look like a clown for those few moments. After that’s all sorted, I go in with the foundation, usually the Tarte Amazonian Clay (seriously has magical properties), and when it’s all buffed & blended, i’m left with a very natural, healthy looking glow and flush of color on the cheeks.

For a more light-weight & dewy base:

I go for a more toned down highlight and blush, but still apply in the same way. I’ve been loving the new Bare Minerals Complexion Rescue as the base for this type of look, I like it cause it helps my skin to stay looking like skin, and sets beautifully under a powder. I’ll grab the Becca Shimmering Skin Perfector in the shade Moonstone as a highlight. While it’s still an absolutely gorgeous highlight, it’s a little warmer and more of a golden-y sheen that won’t blind anyone. Sometimes I want to slather this stuff all over (okay, so I have done it—and loved it). For the blush i’ll grab another NYX Rouge Cream Blush, but this time in the shade Natural. It’s much more muted, and has some beige tones to it, so it’s a tad bit warmer. These two products translate perfectly under a dewy base. Want to have the dewy glow without looking like you’ve just dumped water on your face? Try a very finely milled setting powder, like the NXY HD Finishing Powder. It combats extra shine but still lets all of that luminosity come through.

What’s your favorite way to get the glow?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: TEN BEAUTY YOUTUBERS YOU SHOULD START WATCHING RIGHT NOW
item.content:encoded:
Hiya! 

It's no secret that I have a bit of an obsession with YouTube. It started with finding funny and silly videos to send my friends as a break from work or to liven up a rather dull weekday evening. I eventually stumbled into a beauty vlogger, by the name of essiebutton. My eyes were split wide open! I have been a closet makeup-obsessor for so long, thinking that I would come off as too girly or high maintenance if I showed anyone my true colors(....of lipstick, eyeshadow, blush, etc.) 

After watching essiebutton for a while (and of course becoming hooked on her second channel, essiebuttonvlogs), I discovered a whole world of people expressing who they are and their passions to the whole world. I am fascinated by this. Blogging is one thing. It takes courage, persistence, and honesty. But to be on camera damn near all the time is so brave! Not to mention that these ladies (and gentlemen) become amazing photographers and film editors. I mean, to find something you enjoy (whether it be beauty, fashion, books, whatever) and find a way to share it with the world, collecting the skills you need to succeed along the way? THAT'S THE DREAM, PEOPLE. 
Many of these ladies also have blogs! (will link everything below) Their awesomeness just keeps on growing. 

Needless to say, I became hooked, and I am still hooked. Here's some gals that I watch religiously and strongly suggest you do as well. 
(in no particular order)

Essiebutton
Estee is quirky, funny, and so completely down to earth. She may or may not be my spirit animal. She's got the cutest greyhound named Reggie, and talks her viewers through many-a-makeup-tutorials, her latest fashions, and what products she's loving. When i'm feeling like I need a laugh, or a little jazz up to my normal makeup routine that won't be too in your face, I find my way to one of her many wonderful videos. 
Estee's blog: http://www.essiebutton.com/ 

Heyclaire
Probably the coolest chick around. She lives in LA, rocks some of the best hair i've ever seen, and gets real about beauty products that work and don't. She also does vlog style videos, and is a bomb-a$$ photog. 
Claire's blog: http://www.heyclaire.com/

Thebeautycrush
Sammi from the beauty crush was the second gal I started watching on YouTube. She's hilarious, and so, so real with her viewers. She does amazing makeup tutorials and fashion videos, but also puts out some great advice videos for other gals that can relate! She's got some cute pups of her own, as well! 
Sammi's blog: http://www.beautycrush.co.uk/

Viviannadoesmakeup
Anna is another soul sister of mine. Lover of the minimal look for everyday that gets a bit of a twist now and then and changes often. Just because you love minimal makeup doesn't mean you can't change it up! She also has a wardrobe that pretty much mirrors mine, monochromatic with a host of pretty, flowy tops. "Her get ready with me" videos are some of my favorites. 
Anna's blog: http://www.viviannadoesmakeup.com/

Lily Pebbles
Lily is such a cool person who I always think of when I am with my life-long friends. She does a lot of videos on beauty, but also incorporates her family and friends quite often, which is really refreshing. 
Lily's blog: http://www.lilypebbles.co.uk/

RachhLoves
Rachel is definitely someone i'd want to be friends with. Not only does she describe her skin type as being almost identical to mine (so I follow her recommendations quite closely), but she's hilarious. Everything I want in a friend. Feel my pains, tell me what works, and make me laugh. :) 

Fleur DeForce
Fleur is a great gal to trust for makeup tips and tricks. She gives her thoughts on all kinds of different products, and hits both drugstore and high end. Some of my favorite videos of hers are the "Top 10 Under Ten" style. She features ten of the best products in various categories (mascara, concealer, foundation, blush, you get the deal) under ten pounds. (now for those in the US and elsewhere, these items may come in over ten of your currency, but it's never too bad! She's also got the cutest family of furballs you've ever seen! (you can follow them @furdeforce on Instagram). 
Fleur's blog: http://fleurdeforce.blogspot.com/

Ingrid Nilsen
Ingrid is the girl everyone can relate to. She's funny, honest, and makes beautiful videos. She likes to get down to who people are as humans, as well as what is fun to slap on your face with makeup. I've never met someone who's into watching beauty vloggers and doesn't love Ingrid. 

Amelia Liana
Amelia is downright hilarious. She's super honest, talks about products she genuinely loves and uses, and is fearless with fashion. She's got a cute pup also, Duke. Her vlogs are some of my favorite! 

Tati
Tati tells the truth. She does these wonderful videos testing out and reviewing products—right on camera. Want to know if a foundation lasts on your face? Watch Tati. Want to know if a new beauty launch is worth the hype? Watch Tati. Want to get a real-life review of products you've been eyeing? WATCH TATI! Need I say more?

Now, since I mentioned above that blogging requires honesty, i'll get real with you here. I watch many, many more YouTubers than just those ten. So many that the full list would have you all wondering if I ever do anything else with my time. YouTube is essentially my Netflix. It was very hard to narrow down this list, but I think you'll really enjoy those ladies! 

Do you have any favorite YouTubers?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: THE NEW CHANEL LAUNCH THAT'S WORTH THE CASH
item.content:encoded:
I was in Nordstrom the other day browsing around the half-yearly sale with my Mom and of course drifted over to the cosmetics counters. This is a dangerous place for me, since I don't happen upon the really higher-end brands that often (purposefully to keep money in my bank). 

I was going swatch crazy, as one would expect, and the SS15 collection from Chanel caught my eye. I have already been lusting over the new Rouge Coco Ultra Hydrating lipstick in the color Mademoiselle, but I hadn't checked out much of the other products for the season. When I saw they had a new cream eyeshadow stick, I had to swatch away, and I was instantly impressed. 
It's called the Fresh Effect Eyeshadow, and it's my new go-to for everyday wear. The colors were gorgeous. There's a purplely color called Campanule, a green called Olivine, a blue, called Azulejo, a rose gold called Laurier Rose, and a dark bronzey shade called Caroube. 

It's not as apparent when you're just testing it on the back of your hand, but I did notice a slight cooling effect, very nice, indeed. I got the rose gold color, number 127 Laurier Rose. When I first applied this to my lids, I realized that the cooling effect felt more like an ice cube being run across the lid. It. was. fabulous. 

I apply this all over the lid then use the finger or a blending brush to blend out the edges. Either leaving it there or taking a light matte brown shade through the crease gives you a great everyday look. The pigmentation is top notch, and it's got the perfect amount of shimmer to make you look snazzy without being so reflective you're blinding people. Not to mention that this formula is super long lasting.

Now, these do come in a at a whopping $34. Hence why I restrained myself to only purchasing one. (But let's be real, i'll likely be back for Caroube soon, I can't resist a bronze eye!) Overall, I say these are worth the money, if you want a really great quality, go-to eye shadow for the summer. 

Have you tried any cream eyeshadow sticks that I should get my hands on?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: THE NAIL POLISH I CAN'T STOP WEARING
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to nail polish, i've been known in the past to be a bit of a hoarder. I would buy a new color every time I was in the store, I built up quite the collection. Brights, neutrals, darks—I had them all.

I recently did a nail polish clear out, where I gifted a ton of colors. I had to get very real with myself about how much I would actually wear something. In doing this, I found that I was only left with neutrals, dark berry shades, and reds. Since it's getting warmer, i'm definitely gravitating towards the neutrals. I have a lot of nudes, browns, and pastels. Out of these i've had one color on my nails for about 2 months straight. When it chips, I take it off and promptly reapply.

Alright, alright, i'll tell you what it is: Revlon Colorstay Gel Envy in the shade Checkmate.

It's a gorgeous pale nudey-beige. The perfect nude, I'd venture to say. I'm a pale girl, and it doesn't wash out or blend in with my skin (which is a plus, shout out to my fellow pale gals). 

The formula looks opaque with just two coats, and it lasts really well without chipping. I've been using it with a Seche-Vite top coat, and I'm pretty much addicted.

What's your favorite nail color for spring?
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: MISSION: SAVE MY SKIN
item.content:encoded:
I've been having a hell of a time with my skin lately. I'm talking, breakouts everyday—and the painful kind that take over your concentration and hurt really bad. I also naturally have very red, blotchy, uneven skin with many acne scars and hyper pigmentation. To top it all off, my skin basically eats makeup. I know, that sounds gross, but I don't know how else to describe it. It soaks right in by the end of the day and I've also been trying new products to reduce this (more on that at a later date).

Part of my problem is my love for products. Skincare, makeup, hair, I tend to want all of the things for all of those. Also, I'm obsessed with beauty youtubers, so I sometimes take their recommendations to mean I should go buy that right now. Which, is entirely in my own head, but I trust these ladies! (since most of them have similar skin types or tones to me) Anywho, I got on a bit of a binge trying out samples of different products. Both high end and drugstore; I was trying tons of cleansers, treatments, masks, moisturizers, and primers. I usually try different makeup quite often, and it doesn't cause too many problems. But, when trying new skincare—I put my poor face through the ringer. I kept thinking "oh this will sort itself out in a few weeks, it's just an initial reaction", but in a few weeks I was likely on to something else new and shiny, causing more problems. I got to the point where I was truly upset on a daily basis when I would take off my makeup and see the state of my skin. I didn't feel confident to have my makeup off around my boyfriend of over a year whom I live with, which just doesn't suit me. I came to terms with it being my own doing, and if it was going to change, I had to chill out on the product testing mania. 

So, I did some research (yes, via youtube and blogs), and found people with similar issues describing what worked for them. I settled on two main products (one of which I had used in the past) to add into the few staple items I never stopped using—and I decided to stick with them to see how they worked. Which means I went out on a limb I don't often visit: purchasing the full size product. Now, my skincare regimen looks like this: 

Morning

Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser (anyone else been using this since around age 14??)
Thayers Witch Hazel with Aloe Vera (I get the lavender scent, but i've also used the rose and loved it as well)
Juice Beauty Blemish Clearing Serum 
Clean and Clear Morning Burst Hydrating Gel moisturizer
Origins GinZing refreshing eye cream

Evening (Very similar, I know—Consistency really is key here!)

Liz Earle Cleanse & Polish Hot Cloth Cleanser
Thayers Witch Hazel with Aloe Vera 
Juice Beauty Blemish Clearning Serum
Clean and Clear Morning Burst Hydrating Gel moisturizer (focusing only on my dehydrated areas, avoiding t-zone)
Yes to Cucumbers Soothing Eye Gel

 

As for the two products that i've recently added:

The first of the three is the Juice Beauty Blemish Clearing Serum. I heard about this from many people, but one gal who I think is the awesomest, HeyClaire (seriously, she's awesome, subscribe to her channel A$AP like Rocky), gave this product a very great review. It's known to not only prevent new breakouts, but also to start breaking up and fading any scaring. (a desperate need of mine).

The second new item is the Liz Earle Cleanse & Polish. I got a sample of this in my Birchbox about a year ago. This was before I got into cleansing balms and oils—also know as the lazy girls savior for removing makeup—so I wasn't that into it. I pulled it back out recently, and quickly fell in love. It works wonders at breaking down and removing makeup, and it's natural ingredients are so gentle and good for the skin. (Hint: if you're in the US you can get your hands on Liz Earle products through Birchbox, which is fabulous because hello—Points! :) ) 

I've been rocking those routines for a few weeks and things seem to be looking up—I will keep you posted!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: GETTING OUR PUPPY: VOL 2
item.content:encoded:
As stated in a previous post, we’re getting a puppy! A beautiful, 12-week old male golden retriever will join our little family at the beginning of August. As you might assume, i’m quite excited. 

A few weeks ago, we were able to go visit the breeder’s home and select which pup from the litter would be ours. Since we went through a breeder and a wait list, we were slated to make the second pick of the males out of the three that were born in this litter. This means that another family went first, met all three puppies, and then picked out theirs. For our turn, we met the remaining two and then decided which puppy would be our Fitz. 

When we picked him, the two boys were six weeks old. When we first met the entire litter, they were three weeks old and quite the sleepy fellows. In three short weeks, their personalities developed a bunch and they were really starting to come into their own. 

The first thing we noticed was the energy levels in the two pups and how different they were! One was very, very energetic and whined a lot. As we picked him up, he was kind of all over the place. The breeder made sure to call out that this is something that can be trained down into a calmer disposition, but it’s likely he’d be a very vocal and energetic dog. The other (also the larger of the two), was the most chill being I’d ever met at that young. He explored, seemed very independent, but was also interested in who the heck we were. He wasn’t startled by any movement or noises, and in general just wanted to hang out. We ended up selecting the latter! 

Here’s some snaps of Fitz after we picked him: 

 

We will visit him a few more times before we finally bring him home, I can barely wait!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: GETTING OUR PURE BRED PUPPY! VOL. 1
item.content:encoded:
I grew up with a dog in my family, and I have loved them ever since we first brought her home. Her name was Mia, she was a mix between and Alaskan Malamute and a Spitz. She was a wonderful pup and the best companion! Late last year, we said goodbye to my sweet girl as she was 15 years old and suffering from a few different medical issues. 

At that point, I knew right away that I wanted a dog of my own. Since Mia was my family's dog, she stayed with my Dad when my brother and I moved out and I instantly missed having a canine around. When I first moved out, one of my roommates was allergic to dogs, so I put my puppy plans on hold. (Admittedly, a good thing for me at the time because I was definitely not ready!) 

After moving in with Nick this past January, I was able to wear him down on getting a dog. He loves dogs, also, but wasn't sure about getting one since there's no doubt that it definitely changes your lifestyle. We talked about when to get one, what breed we wanted, if we wanted a more grown dog or a puppy, and where we wanted to go looking for one. We landed on a puppy golden retriever. In our city, when looking for a puppy that's a specific breed, unfortunately your only real choice is a breeder. I am 100% for adopting dogs from shelters that are in need of good homes, and can honestly say I plan to do so in the future. 

I did a lot of research on breeders in the area, I was adamant about choosing the right one for us. I wanted to make sure they did everything humanely, the pups were loved by the breeder in their first 8 weeks, and the dogs who were being bred were also treated well. I found a few breeders that are not too far from where we live, and started emailing away. Around here, as with many places I would assume, it's very normal to be put onto a wait list. For some breeds, these waitlists can be up to a year long! Knowing this, I put myself on a few, and really thought through my notes to these people so they knew Nick and I genuinely wanted a companion we could love and give a great home to. 

I was lucky enough to be contacted rather quickly by one breeder to let me know that in 2 months time, two litters of pups would be born, and there were still spots available on the list for them. I was elated! We mulled it over for a day or two, to make sure the timing would work out, then decided to go for it! 

Our little ball of fur was born at the beginning of May, and we are going to meet the pups for the first time this week! More information on our pup, our story of getting him, and many pictures to come!
item.dc:creator: crameresusan@gmail.com

item.title: ABOUT SUSAN
30 BEFORE 25
item.content:encoded:
30 BEFORE 25

When I graduated college I was 21, bright eyed, and ambitious. I wasn't exactly sure what I wanted to do with my career, but I knew I wanted to make an impact on the world somehow. I've since put a lot of time and effort into learning about myself, my strengths, and what would make me happy in work. 
This list, however, is (mostly) about things outside of work. My passions that i'd like to get into as hobbies (serious lack of a better term). It's places I'd like to visit, accomplishments i'd like to check off, skills and interests i'd like to keep up that might not be part of my day job. It's evolved some with me over the past 3 years, as I expected it to. I've evolved a lot in the last three years as well, so it only makes sense the list does so with me.

I know tons of these types of lists float around the blogosphere and I've been jotting down goals to include in mine here & there. When making a list of goals there are a few important things I think everyone should keep in mind:
1. A timeline.
If you don't give yourself a deadline to have the goal accomplished, you'll be surprised at how fast it can get pushed to the back of your mind due to all of the other crazy things that go on in life.
2. Personalization.
This seems obvious, but it's seriously important to truthfully feel that each item on your list is tailored to you. Including that deadline I just mentioned.
3. Fun.
Make sure you put some light hearted, fun goals on your list too! You don't want to be all work and no play. Plus, if you load yourself up with all serious goals, it's going to seem more like a chore.

(btw, i'll be 25 on July 18th, 2016!)

Here's my list: 

  1. Attend a music festival (Midpoint Music Festival, October 2014)

    2. Move into my own apartment (March 2014)
  2. Land a job I enjoy and take pride in (January 2014)
  3. Read every Fitzgerald novel (Progress: The Great Gatsby, The Beautiful and The Damned,The Curious Case of Benjamin Button)
  4. Travel to France (October 2014)

    6.Write for the blog twice a week (with a one month benchmark to create the habit) (March + April 2016)
  5. Contribute writing to another blog (The Ahalogy blog; multiple)
  6. Buy a new (personal) apple computer
  7. Create a manageable workout regimen that makes me feel great. (began training with Jill in Dec. 2014)

    10. Grow my hair out to mid-back length (it's about there, i'd say! April 2015)
  8. Purchase the top 10 items on my high-end beauty wishlist

  10. Visit NYC (April 2014)

  13. Read 30 new books (The Girl With All The Gifts, Die Empty, The Virgin Suicides, Cuckoo's Calling, Yes, Please., Not That Kind of Girl, Secret North, The Opposite of Loneliness, Ready Player One, How To Be Parisian Wherever You Are, The Curious Incident of the Dog and the Nighttime, Sacré Bleu, Persepolis, Food: A Love Story, The Hitch Hikers Guide To The Galaxy, Between You & Me, The Silkworm, Then Again, Let's Just Say It Wasn't Pretty, This is Where I Leave You, The Girl On The Train, The Knockoff, The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying, Why Not Me?, The Storied Life of A.J. Fikry, The Martain, Career of Evil, The Boston Girl, So Good They Can't Ignore You, The Vacationers*)
  14. Create my dream home office space
  15. Take my mom to Europe or Belize
  16. Make spaghetti squash (April 2015—NO idea what took me so long!)>
  17. Get a nice camera and put more time into taking photos—dreaming of the Olympus Pen E-PL7 (JULY 2015, Olympus Pen E-PL7 Purchased!)

    23. Buy photoshop and learn how to use it (Sept 2015)
  18. Cook dinner at home three nights a week for two months (March and April 2015)
  19. Visit San Fransisco (May 2014)
  20. Lead a major project start to finish (work) (Brand Voice and Tone Guide, Jan. 2014)
  21. Visit Harry Potter World at Universal Studios (Went with my mom in Oct. 2015!)
  22. Read every Hemingway novel (The Old Man and The Sea, The Sun Also Rises,)
  23. Run a 10k
  24. Create a "Before I Die..." wall in Cincinnati and maintain it for a month.

item.title: Let's Work Together
item.content:encoded:
Let's collaborate. 

I do a few things. Write, strategize, research, take photos, listen, observe, and act. 

I help brands define their voice, tone, and writing style. I help brands use
those elements to build an identity, a personality.

item.title: Portfolio
item.content:encoded:
Voice and Tone for Ahalogy

Ahalogy had a problem. We weren’t communicating in the same way across all functions. Whether it was product features, how our service works, etc., we were all over the place. Different functions in the business even called the same features by different names. Essentially, we were in need of a way to unify our communication. 

I took a personal interest in this and began to research what other companies which have a really strong voice. Specifically Buffer, Pinterest, and Mailchimp. Each of these companies has a voice that is recognizable across many different types of communication, undoubtedly authored by multiple people. The priority they’ve put on voice as a pillar of their brand inspired me and led to me create this for Ahalogy. 

Research began into what Ahalogy has been to date, how we want to portray ourselves in the market, and what information was needed to get us there—on the same page. With my background in communication focussing on how people who work together communicate combined with my love of grammar, I was able to create Ahalogy’s Voice and Tone Guide. 

The Voice and Tone guide is a collection of guidelines on different communication types for all functions dependent upon the intended audience. It was also requested that I provide some helpful tips on common grammatical errors, some of which are stylistic choices. 

Voice is a pillar to any brand and it was an impactful project to spearhead. Working cross functionally is the best way to not only get the right inputs for a project like this, but to ensure quick buy-in and adoption of a new way of working.
